Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then let the phlebotomy needle be made to a length somewhat wide for phlebotomy.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then draw from the blood a moderate quantity, or according to what you see is necessary for that.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do the same with another vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Then loosen the bandage, and apply a medium tourniquet to the two veins: so that the patient is not choked.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And let her go until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	For the wound is healing.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	¶ On Phlebotomy of Veins by Albucasis.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	The veins are beneficial for Albucasis's phlebotomy because they help with alcohol on the mouth, and gum corruption: and bad sores: and splits of the lips, and bad ulcers, even those which are in the nose, and around it.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of phlebotomy for them is that you should have the patient sit before you: and tie his neck with a bandage.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then roll back his lip and look at the two veins: one is on the right side of the lip, and the other is on the left: and the appearance of each is indicated by the darkness of both.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And it is true: because around them are small veins, black.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Therefore cut both with an oblique incision.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	But if you are in doubt and do not know which one it is: then pay attention to the larger of the incisions, and the more apparent of them.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And similarly do this for the two veins that are on the upper lip: and indeed custom most often agrees with this. And cut the two veins that are on the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	Regarding Phlebotomy of the Vein Under the Tongue Following Cephalic Phlebotomy.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	The benefit of the phlebotomy of the two veins that are under the tongue is that cephalic phlebotomy helps with suffocations that occur in the throat, and inflammation of the gums, and illnesses of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the manner of phlebotomizing them is that the patient should sit between your hands facing the sun: and lift his tongue, and look under his tongue from one side for a vein, and from the other side for another vein: and the color of both tends towards blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	Therefore phlebotomize both veins: and be careful not to go too far with your hand when phlebotomizing them.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For arteries lie under them, and it may happen that blood will flow from those arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	Regarding the Three Veins in the Elbow.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	The three veins that are phlebotomized in the elbow, which are phlebotomized according to custom in all people.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And phlebotomy of them is performed in two ways.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Or by pricking with a broad myrtle lancet; or with an olive lancet for fineness: or cutting with a pocket lancet, and it is called Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus Alnesil is, which is suitable for cutting.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And from these there are broad and fine types according to the width of the veins and their tightness. The shape of the myrtle lancet is broad, as you see.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it is suitable for opening concave, full, protruding, visible, thick veins, and those that contain thick, cloudy blood.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this lancet is of narrower width and finer at the tip.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	And it is suitable for bleeding fine veins that contain thin, yellowish blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	Concerning the Phlebotomy of the Basilic Vein.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	The basilic vein, which is one of these three veins, is beneficial for phlebotomy.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because it extracts blood from illnesses that are below the throat and neck, following the chest and abdomen. It is appropriate for the phlebologist to be cautious when performing phlebotomy with this vein, as there is an artery beneath it, so one should proceed with care due to this concern.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If therefore he makes a mistake and adds too much to the puncture of the lancet, he will cut that artery, and there will be a flow of blood.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore, one should not use a sharp lancet for phlebotomy; rather, use a scalpel with Alnesil.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	If the basilica is not clearly visible, then you should move away from it and switch to another one, or seek a branch of it: or in its place, perform phlebotomy on the funiculus brachii.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	For it is clearly visible, and you should cut it with the Anesil lancet, as we have said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	If you wish to perform phlebotomy on it, then before tightening the arm, touch the area until you find the pulse location.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then mark the area with a hot iron, then hold the arm and cut the vein with a concave incision using the Alnesil lancet, as we have said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And be careful that the blow does not fall in the space between the artery location.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you see that as you tighten the ligature, there is swelling in the place you marked with a hot iron, then that swelling is arterial swelling; therefore, avoid it.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	If you see the blood rising during phlebotomy like a child's urine, and it is fine and red, then you know that it is arterial blood.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Then hurry and place your finger on that space for a moment, then remove your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If the blood is cut off (it often does get cut off), then tighten the arm and leave it as is: and the patient should avoid moving that area and be cautious of it.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And let him not move for several days until it is healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	But if the blood does not stop and overcomes you, and there is no medicine available to you at that moment, then cut the artery, if it appears necessary to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For its extremities contract, and the blood is cut off.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take the peel of a date stone, and burn it; take half of it and apply it to the site of the vein constriction with a bandage and powder until another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if the blood is stopped, it is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not, then treat it with what was mentioned before regarding places that stop the flow of blood: and stopping the blood is not difficult in many cases, due to the small area of the wound and the possibility of applying a bandage from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	Concerning the Phlebotomy of the Dark Vein.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	Phlebotomy of the Dark Vein is beneficial in drawing blood from the upper part of the head and the lower part of the body: because it is composed of the branch of the Basilic vein and the branch of the Cephalic vein, as we have said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And it is appropriate for the phlebotomy practitioner to be without fear during the procedure, as there is a nerve under this vein.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	If therefore the practitioner adds pressure during the phlebotomy and finds a nerve, there will be numbness in that area, and healing becomes difficult, and it may not heal completely.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve often appears to the senses.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	If it is hidden in some people and is subtle and not revealed, then you must apply your phlebotomy as you perform it, the cut with Alnesil, and avoid the nerve with all your strength.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	If the vein is between two nerves, then find the vein along its length.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	Concerning the cephalic vein.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	Phlebotomy of the cephalic vein is helpful because it draws blood from the head and benefits ailments of the eyes.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And if you wish to perform phlebotomy on this vein properly, you should do so by piercing it with an olive phlebotomoy knife or a myrtle phlebotomy knife, for it is safer than all other veins because there is no delicate artery or nerve near it.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	However, when performing phlebotomy, you should avoid the head of the biceps with the phlebotomy knife just slightly, and seek a softer area. It does no harm if it is not found on the first percussion, and you can repeat the procedure several times with the phlebotomy.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	However, it may become inflamed in some people when not phlebotomed on the first percussion, but such inflammation does no harm.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	Concerning the usefulness of Phlebotomy and the precautions to be observed in it.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality of phlebotomy and the accidents arising from it, which you must consider for its proper execution.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	Therefore, it is important to know that bloodletting is not administered except for the preservation of health, and its maintenance, and caution against the onset of diseases.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And to perform bloodletting on one of the three veins in the elbow, namely the Cephalic, the Median Cubital, and the Basilic.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And to perform bloodletting at the beginning of spring after fasting, in spring and summer: and in autumn and winter after eating, when signs of fullness are apparent.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And bloodletting should be performed on the first day, or on the third day, after three hours have passed since dawn.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	However, bloodletting administered for illnesses does not have a fixed time; it is performed when circumstances and necessity require it, day or night, at any hour and at any time.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not appropriate to perform bloodletting on children until they reach fourteen years of age.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	A pregnant woman should not be bled except from the fourth month until the seventh month.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	And those who have passed sixty years of age should not be bled.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	When someone wishes to undergo bloodletting for any reason, it is necessary to cleanse their intestines before bloodletting with a gentle enema if there is much retained feces in them: so that the veins near the bloodletting site do not attract noxious putrid substances from the intestines and draw them towards the principal parts of the body.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	The patient should not be bled when they are too full, that is, when they feel nausea from overeating; nor should they be drunk or recovering from drunkenness, until those conditions are removed from them.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Nor should an ill person with dropsy be bled.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And bleeding should be avoided after an attack of colic, vomiting, diarrhea, excessive sexual activity, labor, exercise, wakefulness, fasting, and anything that dissipates strength from the bodily or vital fluids.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Then consider the subtlety of the humors before doing so; if the blood is thick due to food and drinks, and medicines: if it is possible for him to do that.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Then enter the bath if nothing prohibits it; or engage in some exercise to refine the blood.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And perform the bloodletting on his chest around the third day, as we said: and strive to ensure that on that day his body is free from all animal evils such as distress, anger, and fear: and from all bodily ailments such as labor, pain, excessive sweating, and similar conditions.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And ensure that at his place, there are present things whose use has become customary among people due to their aromatic qualities, and pleasant smells and celebrations, in proportion to what is possible.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Then the bloodletter should sit on a cushion that is higher than the cushion used for bleeding: afterwards, he should extend his arm and rub it twice or thrice with his hand.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then tie the vein with a ligature and wrap it twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And let the ligature be moderate, for when it is uneven, either by excess in the ligature, then it impedes the flow of blood; or in softening, then also it impedes the flow of blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after the ligature, it is necessary that the phlebotomist should rub his hands simultaneously until the veins swell and become apparent to the senses.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then the phlebotomist should clean the vein with a little oil, properly and carefully.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then he should place his index finger of the left hand on the vein slightly above the place where he wishes to perform the phlebotomy, so that the vein does not escape and be struck effectively.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	Because the veins are like a fleeing chord at the time of phlebotomy: and they are full of windiness: and when you place the lancet on them, they contract under the lancet, and deceive the phlebotomist, and do not open for the lancet: and if it does open them, it is constricted. Therefore, it is necessary that the phlebotomist be firm and diligent in all these matters.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then remove the lancet.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If the vein therefore opens on the first attempt, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then repeat it at another place nearby or above it quickly: if the area has not become inflamed.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	If it becomes inflamed, or the patient weakens, then leave him for a day or two: and do not apply a ligature.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	For perhaps it will attract a hot abscess.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	Nor shall he enter a bath.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then let bloodletting be repeated, if desired.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	If the incision is small, or the blood flows thinly, and you fear that the amount of blood you wish to extract will not come out: then repeat the bloodletting at the same point along the straight line, and add a little more to the procedure.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And do this with haste, before the place becomes inflamed, for an inflamed area is common around a small procedure in many people.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If you see that it is already inflamed, then do not repeat the procedure on it at all, for nothing excuses this.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And place something from oil residue on it, for it alleviates the flow of blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	And it is better in this case than the oil itself and other oils.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And similarly, administer oil residue in all your bloodletting procedures where you restrict the flow of blood. And this is done with electuaries of alfa herbs and sage, when one of them is applied to the site.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	For blood becomes finer and dissolves when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	If an abscess occurs at the site of bloodletting, which often happens, especially for those who are not accustomed to bloodletting or whose incision is small, then hurry and place a sponge soaked in warm water and salt on the site: and press it for one hour, for it dissolves.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And you should do this after the blood has come out of the vein itself, when it is full, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	If there remains some black or green discoloration in the area for several days, it does no harm; and if you wish, apply something like aloe or dissolved myrrh, or something from mint juice, that is, burnet or something similar to it.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And abscesses and swellings often occur near the venesection site at the Basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	Place your hand on it, then if you find softness upon pressing it, then that swelling is harmful.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Be careful, therefore, not to apply anything to it as we have mentioned.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps blood may flow from that artery.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But apply a plaster to it with something astringent to harden the area.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for it along with the rest of the treatment until it heals.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And you should draw blood from every person in an amount according to their strength.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And what appears from the color dominating the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For if the blood is black, then let it flow until it turns red; and similarly, if you see it to be thick, then let it flow until it becomes thin; and similarly, if it is sharp in nature, let it flow until that sharpness is removed.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And it is necessary for a person who is full, strong, and needs bloodletting, that the venesection be enlarged and on the side; and for one who is weak, it should be the opposite.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is necessary that he extracts it with forceps, and the hole should be tight: and better than what is used in phlebotomy of veins is a transverse cut, not a puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this method of phlebotomy is safe from excessive blood flow and from cutting the nerve: and it is more praiseworthy and safer than phlebotomy by length and width.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And for those who are prone to fainting during phlebotomy, it is necessary that they eat a little bread infused in pomegranate juice before phlebotomy: or scallion, if it is heated: and extract from the blood in three squeezes, or four.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if they have a cold complexion, then let them take bread infused in mithridate syrup, or in aromatic honey syrup with spices, or in fragrant aromatic syrup before phlebotomy.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	If fainting occurs during phlebotomy and the cause is excessive loss of blood, then it is necessary that they drink water mixed with meat and a subtle fragrant syrup: and use aromatics with almond oil, and apply it to their chest: and use other remedies as we have mentioned in the chapter on fainting due to evacuation.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	Whoever wishes to bleed their arm and release their blood gradually: should do so for one whose phlebotomy is necessary due to a large evacuation and whose strength is weak, by releasing the blood little by little according to their strength over consecutive days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	Whoever wishes to bleed their arm and release their blood again, and has a strong body: then let them do so seven or nine hours after their first phlebotomy.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	However, if one wants to attract blood from their body towards the opposite side to which it tends to flow: it must be done for him on the second day, or on the third.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	In a body where there is already much heated and sharp blood, which causes fever to occur: it must be that the blood exits from it all at once, and a large amount should be drawn out: and the incision should be enlarged until syncope occurs; after you have maintained all the conditions of phlebotomy: and place your hand on his pulse near the flow of blood, so that death does not occur due to syncope.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	For this often happens when the phlebotomist is ignorant and fails due to negligence.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	And it is not appropriate when you wish to release the arm and draw blood a second time, if the vein orifice is already closed and the blood's exit is difficult, to press upon it with force and quickly straighten the bent area.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	For that is very bad; indeed, leave it until the second phlebotomy.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Or remove with sharpness from the vein's orifice what has coagulated from the blood, and place upon it some salt dissolved in water.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And place something from Alfarach or Sagzena treacle upon it, and apply light compression until the blood flows out.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	But if the vein is already inflamed, then leave it and do not cover it until the inflammation subsides.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	If necessity compels drawing blood a second time and there is no excuse to avoid it, then either perform phlebotomy on that same spot or on another vein in the other arm.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	However, the vein of the arm is phlebotomized at the Fusaea and Basilica, where they are not found, and they are hidden, because it is composed of them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of phlebotomy is such that the patient should insert his hand into warm water until it turns red and the vein becomes clearly visible.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then tie a ligature with moderate tightness over it in the middle.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then make the incision gradually across the vein, neither too wide nor along its length; and let the opening be wide enough, and when you perform the phlebotomy, do it for a short time above the joint of the hand.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	If the flow of blood is hindered, then immerse your hand again in warm water, and let the blood run into the water until you achieve your goal.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	However, if it is during the summer days, then you are excused from immersing your hand repeatedly in warm water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And indeed, the flow of blood into warm water is most significant during the winter season.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And the phlebotomy of this vein is safer than that of all other veins, because there is no pulsating vein or nerve under it.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	However, the phlebotomy of the Saluatella vein on the right hand relieves ailments of the liver.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is such that you should tie a ligature or squeeze the hand with your hand after immersing it in warm water until the vein swells and becomes clearly visible to the touch.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then cut it across with a scalpel.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you cut it completely, it will not harm her in any way.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And keep it so, without using your hand with the scalpel.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	Below it, the nerves of the fingers are exposed from the flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then place your hand in warm water, and allow the blood to flow into it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not place it in warm water, the blood will coagulate in the vein opening and hinder its flow.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	Therefore, when you have extracted the necessary amount of blood, then apply oil and salt on the vein: so that it does not heal too quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And similarly, you must do this with every tight branch.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	However, the venesection for that vessel should be performed with your left hand, as it relates to diseases of the spleen: and similarly, perform the venesection on it as you did equally in the second one.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	The venesection of the saphenous vein is beneficial for ailments in the lower part of the body, such as ovarian disorders, retention of menstruation, kidney diseases, old ulcers of the thighs and legs, and similar illnesses.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the procedure for its venesection is that the patient should immerse his foot in warm water: and rub it until the veins become prominent: and tie above the joint of the foot with a bandage.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	And the location of the vein is at the heel, visible towards the big toe: and branches from it extend across the surface of the foot.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	Therefore, phlebotomy should be performed on the larger branch of it, or at the heel where the vein converges: for this is better and safer.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	If you perform phlebotomy on the surface of the foot, then be careful not to cut the nerves that lie beneath it.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And place your incision for phlebotomy as if you want to cut across it: and let the phlebotomy be shallow.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	但如果血液流出受阻，那么将脚放入温水中：让血液流入其中，直到它被排空。
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	但如果放血者在第一次误切了静脉，那么再次进行放血时稍微向上一些，因为那个位置是安全的，当你小心避开神经时，不必担心由此产生的不良后果，正如我们所说的。
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	同样地，对于另一只脚的大隐静脉也应同等处理。
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	然而，如前所述，腓静脉的位置是在脚跟的外侧。注意这里的"Sciaticae"可能是指与位置相近的静脉，翻译时可根据上下文理解调整为更合适的术语。如果指的是大隐静脉或小隐静脉在脚跟附近的部分，则可以表述为："然而，如前所述，隐静脉的位置是在脚跟的外侧。" 具体取决于原文的具体指代。
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	并且，对其进行放血可以缓解疼痛，当疼痛是由于热性血液引起时尤其有效。
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	并且，对其进行放血的方法是，病人应尽快进入浴缸：用细长的绷带从疼痛部位侧边紧压到脚跟上方四指处，这样做只是为了达到这个效果。
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When it is therefore apparent, then use the phlebotome to cut it in whatever manner is possible for you, either across or lengthwise: and it is better to make an incision with a knife or to cut it with scissors.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	For its location is safer, and it is very hidden in most people.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	If you do not find it and it does not appear at all to the senses: then cut with a phlebotome one of its branches, and that which is visible on the back of the foot near the heel: be careful of the nerves, and let the blood flow in the quantity you desire.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then loosen the constriction, and place leather over the site of the incision, and secure the area.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	It is healed quickly.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	Regarding Venesection, and the Quality of Its Use.
Caput XCVIII.	Chapter XC VIII.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	Ventose cups are made from horns, and from copper, and from glass.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And venesection is indeed performed in two ways.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	One involves scarification and the extraction of blood, and the other is venesection without scarification.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this venesection which is without scarification is performed in two ways.
Aut enim est cum igne.	One involves the use of fire.
Aut est absque igne.	The other is without the use of fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And the ventose cups that are applied with scarification and the extraction of blood are fourteen locations on the body.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	One of them is Ventosatio Alnocrati, and it is the last of the head. And Alkehel, and it is in the middle of the neck. And ventose plates of Alhagdahim, and they are two plates on both sides of the neck simultaneously. And ventose of the chin, and it is under the jaw below the mouth. And ventose of the two spatulas: and ventose of Alachosos at the end of the tail. And ventose of the two elbows, and they are in the middle of the two arms. And ventose of the two thighs: and ventose of the two heels.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	And indeed, Ventosatio does not draw blood from you through the small veins scattered in the flesh, and because of this, their power does not diminish as it would with phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	Nor should ventosation be administered, whether with fire or without fire, in any illnesses that arise from congestion, until the entire body is evacuated.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	If necessity prompts ventosation due to illness or out of habit, we administer it at any hour at the beginning of the month, at the end of it, and in the middle, and at whatever time it may be.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	This is because there are people who, when the blood multiplies within them to the point where it needs to be extracted through ventosation, find that they have heaviness and swelling in their head.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And there are those among them who find congestion and redness in their face, head, and neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And there are those among them who experience itching in their face and forehead, as well as darkness and dullness in their eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And there is one who scrapes the site of his wound.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And among them is he whose laughter is multiplied.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And there is one who finds the taste of blood in his mouth: or his tongue becomes swollen, and he spits out blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And among them is he whose sleep is multiplied.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And there is one who sees in his sleep blood and redness, and the slain, and wounds, and things similar to these.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When we therefore see any of these things, and especially if it is on the fifteenth day of the month: we then order the wound to be treated, after two or three hours have passed.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	The support for neck ventosity is that it contributes to heaviness in the head, and what is discharged affects the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	However, it is necessary that this be done after the evacuation of the entire body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And this ventosity is in place of a cephalic phlebotomy.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	And it is not allowed for one of cold complexion or who has a catarrh to use it.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it causes him great harm.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	And for that reason, it is not appropriate for elders or those with cold headaches to use it.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	However, one who becomes frequent in its use generates forgetfulness upon himself.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And for that reason it is necessary to instruct the Cupper to remove his hand with the cupping instrument temporarily towards lower areas, fearing from habituation a loss of memory.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	Ventosatio or Alkehel is instead of phlebotomy Fuscae and phlebotomy Basilicae, and for that reason it benefits asthma, and constriction of breath, and splitting of the breathing instrument, and coughing, and fullness.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	And it is necessary to apply the cupping vessel for Alkehel temporarily above, because if it is placed below, it generates weakness in the heart and stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	Ventosatio alhagdahim, however, benefits pains and accidents in the head, and ophthalmia, and migraine, and perforation, and pain in the roots of the teeth: and it is instead of phlebotomy Basilicae.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And it is necessary to instruct the Cupper not to press his hand with incision: so as not to cut an artery, and cause a flow of blood.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	Ventosatio under the chin, benefits ulcers in the mouth, and corruption of the gums, and similar illnesses that are in the mouth: and it stands instead of phlebotomy alieherich, which is on both lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	Ventosatio of the spatulas benefits alchafacham, which is caused by congestion and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	Ventosatio of the inner parts of the two axillae benefits phlebotomy of the three veins, Basilicae, Fuscae, and Cephalicae: because it attracts blood from all those small veins that are in the flesh: and these small veins attract blood from other larger veins until the attraction reaches the three main veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	And you should instruct the Surgeon not to proceed far with the incision: for the place is uncovered by flesh, and beneath it are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	However, the ventose applied to the alchausos benefits hemorrhoids of the anus and ulcers below.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	And you should instruct the Surgeon to use a large ventose and that it be made of air: for the place requires strong suction, and the delicate ventoses might break. The incision should also be deep.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	The ventoses of the legs visibly reduce swelling: for they draw blood from the entire body and alleviate old pains in the kidneys, uterus, and bladder: they induce menstruation and are beneficial for bothor (inflammation) and ademenul (dysmenorrhea): and they serve as a substitute for phlebotomy of the two saphenous veins and alhorcobeni.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	However, they greatly weaken the body and cause syncope to occur in many people.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	And the benefit of ventoses on the alhorcobeni is similar to the benefit of ventoses on both legs.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The quality of the position of ventoses is that you should first place the ventose empty and draw with moderate suction: do not prolong the placement of the ventoses but put them quickly and remove them quickly so that the humors come to the site evenly upon arrival: do not stop repeating this and continuing until you see the area turn red and inflamed, and the reddening of blood appears: then scarify and repeat with gradually increasing suction.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Then consider the condition of the bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	For whoever has delicate flesh with few pores should be scarified once, not more, so that the area does not become ulcerated.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	And instruct the Venotator to enlarge the scarifications and go somewhat deep; and let him moderate the suction with ease, speed, and gentle movement.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	If there is thickening in the blood, then it is necessary to scarify twice.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	Indeed, in the first instance, a path is opened for the refinement of the blood and its dilution: and in the second instance, for the thorough extraction of thickened blood.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	If the blood is very impure, then a third scarification should be performed to achieve the final result.
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	And finally, when we wish to extract the blood gradually or for a short while, one scarification is sufficient for us.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	If we wish to extract a large amount of blood, we should perform multiple scarifications.
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	And if we measure that the blood is thick, then it is necessary to perform a deep scarification: and the equal limit in scarification is the depth of the skin.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	¶ What should be administered from oils at the placement of Venotations, and what should the person being treated beware of.
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	For one whose skin is thick, hard, dark, and whose pores are tight, it is necessary to anoint the areas for Venotations with oils that are opening, soothing, and resolving: if it is in summer, such as oil of squills, or violet oil, or sweet almond oil, or cucumber seed oil.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	And if it is in winter, then narcissus oil, or oil of the lily, or chamomile oil, or sarbotine: and things similar to these.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	If the excess is thick and cold, then use marjoram oil, or oil of balsamite, or oil of wild mint, or anise oil: and things similar to these.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.	If the windiness involves large pores and tender flesh, then they must be prevented from using oil, and after the treatment of windiness, these areas should be washed with rose water, or cold water, or sun-dried water, or cucumber water, or purslane water: and similar substances.
Ille autem cuius sanguis est multae humiditatis, abluat uentosas cum aceto, aut cum aqua myrti, et sumach: et similibus eis.	He whose blood has much humidity should wash the winded areas with vinegar, or with water of myrtle and sumac: and similar substances.
Cuius autem superfluitates sunt grossae, abluat uentosas suas cum uino antiquo, aut cum aqua samsuci, aut decoctione aneti, aut camomillae: et eis similibus.	He whose excesses are thick should wash the winded areas with old wine, or with water of burnt vinegar, or a decoction of anise, or chamomile: and similar substances.
Et oportet, ut caueatur uentosatio in balneo, aut in uestigio balnei, imo oportet, ut administretur post exitum ex balneo per horam, aut per horas duas.	And it is necessary to avoid windiness in the bath or in the footsteps of the bath; rather, it should be administered after exiting the bath for an hour, or for two hours.
Et non oportet, ut dormiat aliquis post uentosationem.	And it is not necessary for anyone to sleep after wind treatment.
¶ Quid est quo oportet ut regatur Ventosandus, aut Phlebotomatus ante uentosationem.	¶ What should be done to regulate windiness or phlebotomy before wind treatment.
ET post eam oportet, ut consideres in primis: tunc si Ventosatus, aut Phlebotomatus sit cholericus, et uincunt super sanguinem eius acuitas et inflammatio: tunc oportet, ut accipiat infrigidantia, sicut granatum muzum: et etiam endiuiam cum aceto et lactuca, et secaniabin, et iuleb: et eis similia.	And after it, one should first consider this: if the winded or phlebotomized person is choleric, and sharpness and inflammation prevail over their blood: then they should take cooling substances, such as pomegranate molasses: and also endive with vinegar and lettuce, and shallot, and rue: and similar things.
Et pone cibaria eius pullos, et carnes ouium sekebiget, et cibos conditos cum agresta: et eis similia.	And place for his food young birds, and mutton that is tender, and seasoned foods with herbs: and similar things.
Et cuius complexio est frigida, oportet ut sumat in potu syrupum de melle, aut de almiua, aut alsecaniabin de seminibus factum: et sumat uinum odoriferum medium, quod est inter uetus et nouum: et praecipiatur, ut utatur paucitate cibi.	And for one whose complexion is cold, he should drink syrup made of honey, or of raisins, or alehoof seed preparation: and let him take moderately fragrant wine, which is between old and new: and it is advised that he use a small amount of food.
Et pone cibum eius pullos, et canebir: et passeres, id est, paruas aues: et pullos columborum issiadebet.	And place for his food young birds, and radishes: and sparrows, that is, small birds: and young doves should be given.
Et oportet, ut potus die uentosationis et phlebotomiae plus sit quam cibus: et oportet, ut detur in potu in quibusdam hominibus in horis tyriaca alfaroch, aut medicamen de musco, id est, muscata, aut alesselithe ante uentosationem: et ante phlebotomiam, aut post: ut confortentur membra principalia, et subtilietur sanguis.	And it is necessary that the drink on windy days and bloodletting be more than food: and it is necessary to give in drink in certain people at specific hours tyriaca alfaroch, or medicine of moss, that is, musk, or aleselithe before bleeding: and before phlebotomy, or after: to strengthen the principal limbs, and to refine the blood.
Et non oportet, ut sumant eam in potu calefacto.	And it is not necessary for them to take it in warm drink.
¶ De Ventosis sine scarificatione.	¶ On Flatulence Without Scarification.
Uentosae autem quae sunt sine scarificatione, sunt Ventosae quae ponuntur super epar, et splenem, et podagram, et super uentrem, umbilicum, et loca renum, et pixidem anchae: quoniam ista membra non sufferunt scarificationem super se.	Flatulences that are without scarification are those that are applied to the stomach, spleen, and gout, as well as on the abdomen, navel, and areas of the kidneys, because these parts do not tolerate scarification.
Et non quaeritur per eas, nisi aut attactio ex membro sanguinis ad membrum: sicut ponimus Ventosam super mammillas in aegritudine fluxus sanguinis narium.	And they seek only to cause the attraction of blood from one part to another: as we place the Ventosa on the breasts in cases of nasal bleeding.
Et utimur eis, ut soluamus a membro uentositatem frigidam inuiscatam in membro: sicut ponimus uentosam super uentrem, et umbilicum.	And we use them to remove cold and unwashed flatulence from one part to another: as we place the ventosa on the abdomen and navel.
Ipsa enim rarificat membrum, et calefacit ipsum, et remouet dolorem propterea, quia resoluit illam uentositatem.	For it rarefies the member, and heats it, and removes pain therefore, because it dissolves that windiness.
Etiam ponitur super renes, quando accidit in eis opilatio, aut lapis.	It is also applied to the kidneys when obstruction or stone occurs there.
Uirtute enim attractionis suae fortasse aperit opilationem, aut eradicat lapidem ex loco suo.	For by the power of its attraction it may perhaps open an obstruction or remove a stone from its place.
Et similiter facit quando ponitur super epar, et splenem apud uentositatem terendam in eis utrisque.	And similarly it does when it is applied to the stomach and spleen for grinding wind in both.
Et istae Ventosae administrantur uacuae cum sectione tantum.	And these Wind Instruments are administered empty with a cut only.
Et quandoque administrantur cum igne.	And sometimes they are administered with fire.
Et quandoque administrantur plenae aqua tepida in aegritudinibus pleuresis: et illud est, ut impleatur Ventosa, et sit magna, aqua calida sola, aut aqua in qua decoctae sint herbae quae conueniunt.	And sometimes they are administered full of warm water in cases of pleurisy: and this is done so that the instrument may be filled with water alone, which should be hot, or with water in which herbs that are suitable have been decocted.
¶ Forma Ventosae administratae cum igne.	¶ Form of the instrument administered with fire.
Sit amplitudo orificii eius duorum digitorum apertorum, secundum quod formauimus: et quantitas eius in profundo sit medietas palmi: et sit in latere eius in loco qui est circiter medium eius, foramen paruum, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum acus: fiat ex aere simul, aut citrino, grossorum marginum, lenium, aequalium, tersorum: ut non laedat membrum apud positionem suam super ipsum: et sit in medio eius uirga transuersa ex aere, aut ferro, ubi ponitur candela cum igne.	Let the size of its opening be that of two spread fingers, as we have formed it: and let the depth of it be half a palm: and let there be a small hole on its side at a place around the middle, with a size sufficient for a needle to enter: it should be made of brass or copper with thick, smooth, even edges so that it does not injure the part where it is placed upon it: and let there be a transverse rod in the middle of it, made of brass or iron, where a candle with fire is placed.
Et iam fit haec uentosa magna, maior ea quam narrauimus, et parum minor illa, secundum aegritudines et aetatem eius qui utitur.	And now this ventosa is made larger, greater than what we have described, and slightly smaller according to the illness and age of the person who uses it.
Ventosae enim puerorum, et extenuatorum sunt aliae, quam uentosae uirorum, et grossorum corporum.	For the windy conditions of children and those who are thin, there are others [methods], than those for windy conditions of men and those with large bodies.
Qualitas autem ponendi hanc uentosam cum igne super membrum, est, ut accendas licinium cum igne ex lino decenter, aut candelam paruam ex caera: et pone eam super medium uirgae transuersae quae est in medio uentosae: ut sit accensus ignis circiter inferiorem partem uentosae, ut non comburatur corpus infirmi.	The quality of placing this windy device with fire above the limb is to light licinium with fire from flax appropriately, or a small candle from tallow: and place it above the middle cross-piece which is in the center of the windy device: so that the burning fire is around the lower part of the windy device, so that the body of the sick person is not burned.
Deinde ponatur super membrum: et digitus sit super foramen quod dixi, donec quando tenemus uentosam: dum indigemus, auferamus digitum, et egredietur uapor super illud foramen, et soluetur uentosa statim.	Then place it above the limb: and let a finger be on the hole that I mentioned, until when we hold the windy device: whenever we need, remove the finger, and vapor will come out through that hole, and the suction of the windy device will be released immediately.
Deinde igni licinium secundum modum suum, et itera eam, si indiges illa.	Then light the flax with fire according to its manner, and repeat it if you need it.
In Ventosa autem quae administratur in aegritudine pleuresis cum aqua, non est uirga transuersa, neque foramen: et non administratur, nisi quia impletur aqua, et ponitur super membrum tantum.	In the windy device that is administered for pleurisy with water, there is no crosspiece or hole: and it is not used except because it is filled with water and placed on the limb only.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et haec Ventosa quanto plus est magna, ut capiat aquam multam, est melior.	And the larger this windy device is, so that it can hold more water, the better it is.
¶ De suspensione Sanguisugarum.	Paragraph on the Suspension of Bloodletting Cups.
Caput XCIX.	Chapter XCIX.
Sanguisugae non administrantur in pluribus, nisi in quibus membris non est possibilis positio uentosarum, propter paruitatem eorum, sicut labium, et gingiua, et eis similia.	Bloodletting cups are not administered on many parts of the body unless it is not possible to position windy devices due to their delicacy, such as the lip, gums, and similar areas.
Aut in membro denudato a carne, sicut digitus, et nasus, et eis similia.	Or in a member stripped of flesh, such as a finger, and nose, and things like these.
Et qualitas utendi eis est: ut ueneris ex Sanguisugis quae sunt in aquis dulcibus, mundis a putredinibus.	And the quality of using them is: to use leeches from waters that are sweet and clean of decay.
Deinde dimittantur die et nocte in aqua dulci, donec famelicae sint, et non remaneat in uentre earum aliquid.	Then let them be placed day and night in sweet water until they are hungry, and there remains nothing in their belly.
Deinde euacuetur corpus in primis cum phlebotomia, et cum uentosis.	Then let the body be evacuated first with bloodletting and for flatulence.
Deinde absterge membrum infirmi, donec rubeat.	Then clean the affected member until it reddens.
Postea ponantur super ipsum.	Then place them upon it.
Cum ergo implentur, et cadunt, et est possibilis suctio loci cum uentosa, tunc est magis ultimum in iuuamento: et si non, tunc ablue locum cum aceto.	When they are full and fall, and suction with bellows is possible, then it is most useful for treatment; and if not, then wash the area with vinegar.
Deinde cum aqua multa, et fricetur, et exprimatur.	Then with much water, rub it and squeeze it.
Quod si prolongatur cursus sanguinis post casum Sanguisugarum, et est illud resudando: tunc infunde pannum lini in aqua frigida, et pone ipsum desuper, donec abscindatur resudatio.	If the flow of blood is prolonged after the application of leeches and it continues to ooze: then soak a linen cloth in cold water and place it on top until the oozing stops.
Quod si multiplicatur sanguis, tunc pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, aut gallas, et similia eis ex stipticis: donec abscindatur sanguis.	If the blood continues to increase, then powder zegi ground, or gallnuts, and things like them from astringents: until the bleeding stops.
Aut ponantur super locum medietates fabarum excorticatarum: et dimittantur, donec adhaereant fabae in loco, nam sanguis abscinditur.	Or apply split and peeled bean poultices to the area: and leave them until the beans adhere to the wound, for then the blood will stop.
Et oportet si necessaria est iteratio Sanguisugarum, quando est possibile, mutare eas.	And if it is necessary to use leeches again, when possible, change them.
Si autem prohibentur Sanguisugae a suspensione, tunc abstergatur locus cum sanguine recenti.	If leeches are prevented from hanging, then the area should be cleansed with fresh blood.
Aut fige acum in locis, donec egrediatur aliquid ex sanguine.	Or fix an acuminated instrument in the place until some blood comes out.
Deinde ponantur, nam ipsae quando sentiunt aliquid ex sanguine, adhaerent statim.	Then apply them, for when they sense that some blood has come out, they will adhere immediately.
Quando ergo uis ut cadant, pulueriza super eas aliquid ex aloe trito, aut salem, aut cinerem: et cadent statim.	When you want them to fall off, sprinkle some powdered aloe, salt, or ash on them; they will fall off immediately.
¶ Partis Secundae Finis.	End of the Second Part.
¶ Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars III.	¶ Book of Surgery by Albucasis, Part III.
¶ Sermo uniuersalis de restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus.	¶ Universal Discourse on the Restoration, Dislocation, and Treatment of Sprains, and Similar Conditions.
Caput I.	Chapter I.
Hoc Capitulum etiam multotiens est necessarium in arte Medicinae, et est restauratio fracturae, et dislocationis accidentium in ossibus.	This chapter is also often necessary in the art of medicine and deals with the restoration of fractures and dislocations of bones.
Scitote o Filii, quia iactant se de hoc Capitulo stolidi medicorum et uulgi, et qui non inspexerunt unquam antiquorum librum, neque legerunt ex eo literam.	Know this, my sons, because there are foolish physicians and common people who speak about this chapter without having ever examined any ancient books or read from them.
Et propter hanc caussam fit, quod iste modus ex scientiis in terra nostra est priuatus.	And because of this reason, it is that this method is kept private among the sciences in our land.
Et ego non obuiaui in eo unquam bono omnino, et non adeptus sum ex eo illud, quod sum adeptus nisi propter longitudinem lectionis librorum antiquorum, et studium super intellectum eorum, donec extraxi scientiam illius ex eis.	And I have never fully encountered anything good in it unless through the length of reading ancient books and studying to understand them, until I extracted that knowledge from them.
Deinde adhaesi experimento et studio longitudine uitae meae.	Then through experience and long study throughout my life.
Et iam descripsi uobis ex illo in hoc Capitulo totum quod continet scientia mea: et super quod praeteriit experimentum meum, postquam abbreuiaui illud uobis, et liberaui illud ex occupatione elongationis, et abbreuiaui illud fine abbreuiationis, et ostendi illud fine declinationis: et formaui in eo formas multas ex formis instrumentorum quae administrantur in eo, cum sit ex additione declinationis, sicut feci in duobus Capitulis praecedentibus.	And now I have described to you from that in this Chapter all that contains my knowledge: and beyond which my experience has passed, after I have abridged it for you, and freed it from the occupation of lengthening, and abridged it at the end of abbreviation, and shown it at the end of declination: and formed many shapes in it from the shapes of instruments that are used in it, since it is by addition of declination, as I did in two preceding Chapters.
¶ Summae, et collectiones ex esse fracturae ossium, ex eis quarum praemissio necessaria est, antequam incipiamus rememorationem membrorum fractorum, et diuersorum, si uniuscuiusque.	Here are the summaries and collections concerning fractures of bones, from those whose preliminary information is necessary before we begin to recall the fractured members and various conditions specific to each.
Caput II.	Chapter II.
Oportet, ut dicamus in prologo huius Capituli, summas sermonis, et capitula, ad quarum intellectum cogitur in primis artifex ad stationem super earum ueritatem: scilicet ut uos, et qui sunt prompti, sciant, uel addiscant hanc artem nobilem, et alii a uobis.	It is necessary that we say in the prologue of this Chapter the main points and headings, understanding which the craftsman must first be set upon their truth: namely, so that you and those who are quick may know or learn this noble art, and others from you.
Dico, ergo, quod quando accidit alicui fractura, aut dislocatio, aut torsio, aut casus: tunc oportet, ut properes in primis ad phlebotomandum eum, et soluendum ipsum, aut utraque simul: si non prohibeat aliquid, sicut debilitas uirtutis: aut est ille cui accidit aliquid ex illis puer, aut senex decrepitus: aut est tempus uehementis caloris, aut uehementis frigoris ualde.	I say therefore that when someone sustains a fracture, dislocation, torsion, or fall: then it is necessary to hurry first to bleed them and reduce the swelling, or both at once: unless something prohibits this, such as weakness of strength: or the one who has sustained any of these injuries is either a child or an elderly person unable to withstand treatment: or it is a time of extreme heat or severe cold.
Deinde sit contentus in cibo suo, oleribus frigidis, et carnibus auium, et haedorum: et prohibe uinum, et carnes grossas, et repleri ex cibis et omni cibo qui replet uenas sanguine.	Then let him be content with his food, cold herbs, and the meat of birds and goats: and forbid wine, fatty meats, and foods that fill the veins with blood, and all such foods.
Donec quando securus sis ex apostemate calido, et non times effusionem materiei ad membrum: tunc redeat infirmus ad regimen suum primum cum quo cucurrit consuetudo eius.	Until you are sure of a warm abscess and do not fear an outpouring of matter onto the limb: then let the patient return to his original regimen with which habitually ran his routine.
Cum ergo incipit os fractum restaurari, tunc oportet, ut cibetur infirmus cibis nutrientibus nutrimento multo, grosso, graui, in quibus sit uiscositas: sicut cibaria facta ex tritico cocto cum aqua, et rizum, et capita, et pedes, et uentres uaccarum, et oua, et pisces recentes: et uinum grossum, et similia illis.	When a fractured bone begins to heal, then it is necessary that the patient be fed nourishing foods with much substance, thick and heavy, in which there is viscosity: such as dishes made from boiled wheat with water, rice, head and feet of calves, eggs, fresh fish: and heavy wine, and similar things.
Cum hoc enim regimine fit coagulatio fracturae uelocius, et melius.	With this regimen, the healing of the fracture occurs faster and better.
Et scias, quod ossa fracta, quando sunt in uiris qui sunt in prima senectute, et decrepitis, non est possibile, ut continuentur et consolidentur secundum naturam suam semper, propter exiccationem membrorum eorum: et consolidantur et continuantur quae ex eis sunt in fine lenitatis, sicut ossa puerornm paruorum.	And you should know that bones which are fractured in those who are in the early stage of old age and are weak do not always heal naturally due to the drying out of their limbs: they heal and unite when they reach a state of softness, just as the bones of very young children do.
Verumtamen natura annectit super os fractum ex omni parte aliquid simile glutino, in quo est grossitudo, quo adhaeret et stringit ipsum, donec conglutinantur adinuicem, et ligantur adinuicem, donec uenit in fine fortitudinis et firmitudinis, sicut fuit in primis, donec non prohibet ipsum aliquid ab operationibus suis: et propter hanc caussam est necesse, ut ponas nutrimentum infirmi cibaria, in quibus sunt grauitas, et uiscositas, et grossitudo, sicut diximus.	Nevertheless, nature attaches something similar to glue around the fractured bone on all sides, in which there is viscosity, by which it adheres and binds until they unite closely and are bound together until they reach a state of strength and firmness as they were initially, until nothing prevents them from performing their functions: and for this reason it is necessary to give the patient food that contains heaviness, viscosity, and thickness, as we have said.
Et scias, quod fracturae species sunt diuersae, secundum diuersitatem membrorum: quoniam fractura cruris, est diuersa a fractura ossis capitis: et fractura ossis pectoris, est diuersa a fractura ossis dorsi: et similiter reliqua membra omnia diuersa existunt adinuicem: et ego ueni cum rememoratione omnis speciei fracturae expositae in Capitulo suo distinctae ab alia.	And you should know that the types of fractures are diverse according to the diversity of limbs: because a fracture of the leg is different from a fracture of the head bone, and a fracture of the rib bone is different from a fracture of the spine bone, and similarly all other limbs differ from one another. And I come with the recollection of every type of fracture laid out in its distinct chapter.
Et diuersificantur species fracturae ossis etiam in seipsa.	And the types of bone fracture vary even among themselves.
Quoniam fit fractura eius arcuata, praeter quod accidant in ea astellae.	Since it is an arched fracture, except that splinters also occur in it.
Et quandoque fit fractura eius secundum longitudinem ossis: et sunt fracturae eius satagiae, id est, astellae, et additiones procedentes, sicut sunt in calamo, cum aptatur cultello ad scribendum.	And sometimes the fracture occurs along the length of the bone: and these fractures have splinters, that is, fragments, and protrusions, just as they are in a reed when it is prepared with a knife for writing.
Et non procedentes: et est fractura cum uulnere et disruptione in capite: et est fractura fissura parua.	And without protrusions: and there is a fracture with a wound and separation at the head: and it is a small crack fracture.
Et omni speciei est ingenium, uel instrumentum proprium in restauratione eius, secundum quod ueniet rememoratio eius, distincta in locis suis.	And every type has its own skill or instrument proper for its restoration, as it will come to mind, distinctly in its place.
Et ex eo quo cognoscitur fractura ossis, est tortuositas eius, et ipsius eminentia: et apparitio eius sensui, et sonitus eius quando comprimis ipsum manu tua.	And from this it is known that a bone fracture is characterized by its curvature and its prominence: and its appearance to the sense, and its sound when you press it with your hand.
