Quando ergo non est in loco tortuositas apparens, neque sonitus apud tactum tuum cum tangis os cum agitatione, neque inuenit infirmus magnum dolorem: tunc non est illic fractura, imo possibile est, ut sit tortuositas, aut fissura parua: non ergo oportet, ut moueas ipsum cum manu et compressione omnino, imo pone super ipsum ex medicinis, quarum uenit rememoratio, post momentum illud quod conuenit loco: deinde stringatur strictura subtili.	When there is no apparent curvature in the place, nor a sound upon touch with some pressure, and the patient does not feel much pain: then there is no fracture there, but it is possible that there is curvature or a small crack. Therefore, you should not move it at all with your hand and compression, but apply medicines when they come to mind after the appropriate time for the place: then bind it tightly with a fine bandage.
Et scias, quod locus quando arcuatur, et scinditur in duo, praeter quod accidant in eo satagiae, uerumtamen remouetur omnis pars a compari sua: tunc oportet tibi, ut incipias ab hora tua ad rectificationem eius, aequando ipsum antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And know that when the place is arched and split into two parts, except for splinters occurring in it, all parts are separated from their counterparts. Then you must begin at your hour to correct it, equalizing it before a hot abscess occurs.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum, tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec quiescat apoestema.	If a hot abscess should occur, then allow him several days until the abscess subsides.
Deinde aequa ipsum secundum quemcunque modum potest ex lenitate et ingenio.	Then treat it equally in whatever manner is appropriate from gentleness and ingenuity.
Et scias, quod restauratio eius, et ipsius aequatio, est facilior quam ossis, in quo accidunt satagiae.	And know that the restoration and equalization of it is easier than that of a bone, in which contractions occur.
Deinde stringe ipsum, secundum quod ueniet tibi rememoratio eius.	Then compress it as you will remember how.
Si uero in osse sunt satagiae, tunc necessaria est extensio huius membri fracti ex duabus partibus, si manus sit, aut pes: aut cum manu tua, si membrum est paruum: aut cum duobus funibus, aut cum fune et manu.	If there are contractions in the bone, then it is necessary to extend this fractured limb from both parts, if it is a hand or foot; or with your hand, if the member is small; or with two ropes, or with one rope and one hand.
Et sit positio tua qua ponis membrum super locum aequalem, secundum figuram suam naturalem, donec quando extenduntur partes membri fracti: tunc conare, ut redire facias illas additiones omni ingenio, et secundum quemcunque modum potes in locis suis: et caue secundum fortitudinem tuam, ne accidat super infirmum per operationem tuam dolor, neque laesio: et conare secundum fortitudinem tuam, ut applices unum duorum ossium cum socio suo, secundum meliores formas.	And your position should be such that you place the limb on an equal surface according to its natural shape until the parts of the fractured member are extended; then try to return all additions with ingenuity and in whatever manner you can to their proper places: and beware, within the limits of your strength, that no pain or injury occurs to the patient through your operation: and strive within the limits of your strength to apply one bone to its partner according to better forms.
Et oportet in illa hora, ut tentes et tangas ipsum manu tua.	And it is necessary at that hour to try and touch it with your hand.
Si ergo uides illic aliquid diuersum, rectifica ipsum, et aequa illud per quantitatem tuae uirtutis.	If you see something different there, correct it and equalize it according to the extent of your ability.
Et caue extensionem uehementem, et compressionem fortem, sicut faciunt multi stolidorum.	And beware of violent extension and strong compression, as many foolish people do.
Multotiens enim faciunt accidere per operationem illam suam apostema calidum, aut contractionem in membro: sicut iam uidimus illud ex operationibus eorum multotiens.	For they often cause the formation of a hot abscess or contraction in the limb through their operations, as we have already observed from their many procedures.
Deinde annecte post aequationem, et decentem operationem, et stricturam illius membri, et quietem, et tranquillitatem: et mone infirmum super ipsum.	Then attach after the adjustment, and perform the appropriate procedure, and secure that member, and rest, and calm: and instruct the patient about it.
Et fac ipsum cauere, ne moueat ipsum in hora suarum uigiliarum, et somni sui apud reuolutionem suam, et agitationem suam, et apud egestionem suam, et omnes motus suos ultima uirtute sua.	And make him beware not to move it during his waking hours, and at the turning of his sleep, and at his agitation, and at his expulsion, and in all his movements with utmost caution.
Et ut caueat, ne sit positio membri positio cum qua sequatur dolor.	And that he be cautious not to place the member in a position that causes pain.
Quod est, quia quando sentit in dispositione positionis membri dolorem, aut laesionem: tunc oportet, ut permutes ipsum ad dispositionem aliam ab illa cum qua non sentiat dolorem.	This means that when he feels pain or injury in the position of the member, then it is necessary to change its position to one in which he does not feel pain.
Et caue cum illo, ut sit positio eius illa aequalis, recta: ut non accidat in membro tortuositas, quando restauratur.	And be careful with him so that his position is equal and straight, so that no curvature occurs in the member when it is being restored.
Et qualitas stricturae membri fracti est, secundum quod narro.	And the quality of securing the fractured member is as I have described.
Scias, quod membra fracta diuersificantur in paruitate sua, et eorum magnitudine, et ipsorum forma.	Know that fractured members differ in their delicacy, and in their size, and in their form.
Quae ergo ex eis sunt parua, sicut brachium, et digitus, et focile, et similia eis, tunc oportet, ut sit inuolutio panni mollis, subtilis.	Those among them that are small, such as the arm, and the finger, and the shinbone, and similar parts, then it is necessary for the wrapping to be of soft, fine cloth.
Quae autem ex eis sunt grossa, sicut coxa, et crus, oportet ut sit in eis inuolutio lata, dura.	Those among them that are large, such as the thigh, and the leg, it is necessary for there to be a wide, firm wrapping.
Quoniam ligamentum latum, connectit membrum magnum, et stringit ipsum ab omni parte strictura aequali, ita quod non ingreditur ipsum macula.	Because a wide bandage connects a large member and secures it from all sides with equal pressure, so that it does not become discolored.
Deinde incipe post euacuationem tuam ab aequatione ponere linimentum conueniens ad illud, in stuppa leni super locum fracturae ipsius.	Then begin by applying a suitable poultice after your evacuation to equalize the area, placing it gently on the site of the fracture.
Deinde incipe inuoluere ligamentum super locum fracturae ipsius tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod meretur membrum: et stringe manum tuam parumper cum ligamento.	Then begin to wrap the bandage around the site of the fracture with three or four layers, depending on what the limb deserves: and hold your hand for a moment with the bandage.
Deinde uade cum eo ad partem superiorem a loco fracturae, et stringe minus quam fuit strictura tua, qua strinxisti locum fractum.	Then proceed to the upper part from the site of the fracture, and hold less tightly than you did when you secured the fractured area.
Deinde elonga te cum inuolutione a loco fracturae parumper, et mollifica stricturam paulatim, donec capias ex loco sano rem magnam.	Then move away from the site of the fracture slightly with the wrapping, and gradually loosen the tightness until you reach a healthy part of the limb.
Deinde accipe uittam aliam, et inuolue eam iterum super locum fractum inuolutionibus.	Then take another bandage and wrap it again around the fractured area with layers.
Postea uade cum inuolutione ad partem inferiorem a fractura.	Then proceed with the wrapping to the lower part from the fracture.
Et sit operatio tua in strictura inuolutionis, et mollificatione eius, secundum quod diximus in inuolutione prima superiore.	And let your work be in the tightening and loosening of the wrapping, as we said regarding the first upper wrapping.
Deinde pone inter inuolutiones ex stuppa leni, aut panno, cum quo aequetur tortuositas fracturae, si est in ea tortuositas: et si non, non ponas in ea aliquid.	Then place between the layers some soft cotton or cloth, which matches the curvature of the fracture if there is a curvature; and if not, do not place anything in it.
Deinde inuolue super ipsam uittam aliam.	Then wrap another bandage over it.
Postea aequa super has inuolutiones astellas decenter factas statim, si non est in loco inflatio, neque apostema calidum.	Then immediately place properly made splints over these layers if there is no swelling or warm abscess in the area.
Si autem in ea est inflatio, aut apostema: tunc pone super eam quod sedet illud apostema, et auferat inflationem: et dimitte eam aliquot diebus.	但如果该区域有肿胀或脓肿，那么放置一个可以支撑脓肿并消除肿胀的东西，并将其留置几天。
Deinde stringe super ipsam tunc astellas.	Then tie strips over it.
Et sint Astellae ex medietatibus cannae latae, rasae, formatae sapienter: aut sint ex ligno unde fiunt cribra, quae fiunt ex pino, aut geraid, id est, ramis palmae, aut calingi: et sit amplitudo omnis Astellae, secundum hanc formam, et hanc eandem figuram.	And let the strips be made from the middle parts of reeds that are flattened and shaped wisely; or they may be made from wood used for making sieves, which is made from pine, or geraid, that is, palm branches, or calingi: and the width of all the strips should be according to this form and this same shape.
Verumtamen oportet, ut Astella quae ponitur super ipsam tracturam, sit grossior et latior parumper, quam reliquae Astellae: et longitudo Astellae sit secundum quod licet membro ex magnitudine et paruitate.	However, the strip that is placed over the wound should be slightly thicker and wider than the other strips: and the length of the strip should be according to the size and shape of the body part.
Deinde stringe super Astellas cum uitta alia, secundum stricturam primam eandem.	Then tie another strip over the strips, according to the same tightening method as before.
Deinde liga desuper cum filis decenter, secundum quod diximus de strictura: et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae plus: et quanto plus elongatur a fractura sit, strictura minor.	Then bind it from above with cords appropriately, as we have said regarding the binding: and it should be such that your binding is tighter over the place of the fracture; and the farther it extends from the fracture, the looser the binding should be.
Et oportet, ut sint fila media in grossitudine et subtilitate, et sint ex lino molli.	And it is necessary that the cords be of medium thickness and fineness, and made of soft linen.
Quoniam si fila sunt grossa, sicut uidi ex operatione stolidorum ponentium fila sua ex chordis lini tortis, est error magnus: quoniam cadit strictura cum eis extra qualitatem.	For if the cords are thick, as I have seen in the work of foolish people who use twisted linen chords for their bindings, it is a great mistake: for such binding falls outside the proper quality.
Et fila subtilia iterum non conueniunt: quoniam tu non consequeris per stricturam cum eis illud quod uis.	And very fine cords also do not suit: for you will not achieve with them the effect that you desire through binding.
Et non oportet, ut sit inter astellam et astellam minus quam digitus.	And it should not be less than the width of a finger between one strip and another.
Quod si laeditur infirmus per extremitates astellarum post stricturam in locis sanis: tunc pone sub eis ex stuppa leni, aut lana carminata, donec nihil laedatur ex illo.	If the patient is injured by the edges of the strips after binding in healthy areas: then place something soft underneath, such as cotton or carded wool, until no further injury occurs.
Quando autem est fractura cum uulnere, et accidit disruptio in cute, ego ueniam cum rememoratione eius in capitulo secundum singularitatem.	When there is a fracture with a wound, and there is a tear in the skin, I will provide information about it as mentioned in the second chapter concerning its particularities.
Et scias, quod non omne membrum fractum oportet ut stringatur cum astellis a primo die.	And you should know that not every fractured limb needs to be set with splints from the first day.
Quod est, quia membrum quando est magnum, non oportet ut ponas superipsum astellas, nisi post quinque dies, aut septem, aut plus, secundum securitatem tuam ab euentu apostematis calidi.	This is because when a limb is large, you should not place splints on it until after five days, or seven, or more, depending on your security from the risk of a hot abscess.
Et iste est modus emplastrorum, quibus restaurabant antiqui, quae ponuntur super fracturam et dislocationem.	And this is the method of plasters, which the ancients used to restore fractures and dislocations.
¶ Modus Emplastri communis abbreuiati, restaurans fracturam, conueniens pluribus complexionibus, praecipue mulieribus, et pueris: quoniam est ex eo super quod non uincit calor, neque frigus.	¶ Method of a Common Abbreviated Plaster for Restoring Fractures, Suitable for Various Complexions, Especially for Women and Children: Since it is such that neither heat nor cold prevails.
Et est, ut accipias ex puluere molendini, et est medulla farinae quae pendet in parietibus molendini apud motum molae: et conficias ipsum sicut est, praeter quod cribelles ipsum cum albugine oui: et pone confectionem eius non spissam, neque subtilem.	And you should take flour dust, which is the fine part of flour that hangs on the walls of the mill due to the motion of the millstone: and mix it as it is, except that you sieve it with egg white. And prepare the mixture not too thick, nor too thin.
Deinde utere eo.	Then use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, restaurantis fracturam, et dislocationem, et torsionem.	¶ Method of Another Plaster for Restoring Fractures, Dislocations, and Torsions.
Recipe almess, et laudani, et acaciae, et enulae, et mugath: et suc, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V et alethil ʒ XX terantur omnia, et cribellentur, et misceantur cum aqua alethil: aut cum albugine oui, si complexio infirmi est calefacta.	Take almonds, laudanum, acacia, elecampane, and mastic. Also take the juice of each, in quantity of 10 grams: myrrh and aloes of both, in quantity of 5 grams each; and alethiolic water 20 grams. All ingredients should be crushed and sieved, then mixed with alethiolic water or egg white if the patient's constitution is heated.
Deinde utere hoc emplastro.	Then use this plaster.
Nam ipsum est bonae compositionis, restaurat ossa fracta uelociter, et confert pluribus hominibus.	For it is of good composition, quickly restores broken bones, and benefits many people.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, quod etiam confert fracturae et torsioni.	¶ Method of Another Plaster, Which Also Benefits Fractures and Strains.
Recipe mugath, et mess, et alteae albae, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V acaciae ʒ VI boli armeni ʒ XX terantur omnia contritione multa, et cribellentur, et conficiantur cum aqua, aut albugine oui: et administrentur.	Take mugwort, linseed, and white lilies, of each 10 ounces; of myrrh and aloes of both kinds, 5 ounces each; acacia, 6 ounces; Armenian bole, 20 ounces. All should be finely powdered and sieved, then mixed with water or egg whites: administer as needed.
¶ Modus Emplastri ad iuncturas, et ossa separata ex locis suis: et sedat dolorem accidentem eis, et scissuram ossis, et fracturam.	¶ Method of Plaster for Joints and Bones Separated from Their Proper Places: It alleviates the pain occurring to them, and heals cracks in the bone, and fractures.
Sumatur lana succida, et submergatur in aceto, et oleo decocto: et ponatur super locum.	Take fresh wool and immerse it in vinegar and cooked oil: then apply it to the affected area.
Et in hoc quidem Emplastro non est uirtus restaurationis, sed est bonum in sedatione apostematis calidi: et expellit dolores proprie.	And in this plaster there is no virtue of restoration, but it is good for soothing hot abscesses and dispelling pain properly.
¶ Modus Emplastri, quod restaurat os fractum.	¶ Method of Plaster That Restores a Fractured Bone.
Sume folia fici surdi, et folia papaueris syluestris: et tere omnia, et fac emplastrum ex utrisque.	Take the leaves of figs and wild poppy leaves: crush all of them and make a plaster from both.
¶ Modus Emplastri abbreuiati, administrati apud restaurationem fracturae ossis: et quando tu uis resolutionem residui apostematis.	¶ Method of a Short Plaster to Be Administered During the Restoration of a Fractured Bone: And When You Wish to Resolve Remaining Abscesses.
Recipe radicis alteae, et camomillae, et florum uiolarum, et farinae herbi, omnium ana partem unam: terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum uino, si non est membrum calefactum.	Take the root of lilies, chamomile, violets' flowers, and herb flour, of each one part: crush all ingredients, and mix them with wine, if the affected member is not heated.
Si uero est calefactum, tunc confice illud cum aqua coriandri humidi, aut cum aqua, et utere eo.	If it is heated, then prepare it with water of wet coriander, or with water, and use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius fortioris in resolutione, quam istud primum, quando accidit apostema durum apud restaurationem membri.	Regarding another stronger method of preparing poultice for the resolution when a hard abscess occurs near the restoration of a member.
Recipe radicis alteae, et seminis lini, et balaustiae, et melliloti, et samsuci, et floris uiolarum, et camomillae, omnium ana, partem unam, terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum aqua salicis, aut cum aqua dulci, aut cum uino.	Take the root of liquorice, and seeds of flax, and soranthus (crab apple), and mellilotus (sweet clover), and thyme, and flowers of violets, and chamomile, of each one part; mix all together and prepare them with willow water, or with sweet water, or with wine.
Totum illud secundum caliditatem membri, et quietem caloris eius.	Apply all of that according to the warmth of the member and the stillness of its heat.
Hippocrates uero non dixit in libro suo, quod ponatur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius, nisi caerotum factum ex caera, et oleo: non aliud: et narrauit, ut sit medium inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem.	Hippocrates, however, did not say in his book that anything should be placed on a member that is being restored after a fracture except for cerotum made of ceres and oil: nothing else. He described it as being of medium consistency between thickness and thinness.
Galeno autem uisum est, ut ponantur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius res, in quibus est exiccatio caliditatis, sicut myrrha, et aloes et olibanum, et similia eis ex eis quae narrauimus.	Galen, however, thought that substances with drying heat should be applied to a member being restored after a fracture, such as myrrh, aloes, and frankincense, and similar ones from those we have mentioned.
¶ Modus Emplastri quod confert ad laesionem et dolorem.	Regarding the method of preparing a poultice that is beneficial for injury and pain.
Recipe mugath, et ciceris, et capillorum hominis incisorum, aut pennae auis, et alteae, et salis partes aequales: terantur, et cribellentur, et conficiantur: et fiat ex eo emplastrum.	Take equal parts of mugwort, chickpeas, cut human hair or bird feathers, liquorice, and salt; mix them together, sieve them, and prepare a poultice from them.
Quantitas autem secundum quam oportet, ut remaneat ligatura, deinde soluatur, est, ut consideres tunc, si non accidit infirmo dolor, neque pruritus, neque mouetur os fractum a loco suo: tunc non resoluas ipsum diebus multis.	The amount needed so that the bandage remains in place and then can be removed is such that you should consider whether pain, itching, or movement of the fractured bone from its position does not occur. If none of these happen, do not remove it for many days.
Quod si accidat ei in loco pruritus uehemens, aut dolor inquietans, aut inflatio: tunc propera, et solue in hora ipsum, et aufer emplastrum ab eo: et accipe pannum lenem, aut spongiam marinam lenem, humidam: et submerge eam in aqua tepida, et ablue cum ea locum, donec quiescat pruritus, et sedetur dolor.	If it should happen that he experiences severe itching or disturbing pain or swelling in the area, then hurry and remove the bandage immediately, and take off the plaster from him: and take a soft cloth or a soft sea sponge, wetted: and immerse it in warm water, and wash the area with it until the itching subsides and the pain is relieved.
Deinde dimitte membrum quiescere una hora.	Then let the limb rest for one hour.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam succidam, submersam in aceto et oleo, aut oleo rosato: et liga super ipsum nocte una, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido, et quiescat inflatio membri, et remoueatur dolor eius.	Then apply a piece of wool soaked in vinegar and oil, or rose oil, to the area: and bind it with this for one night, until you are sure that there is no hot abscess, and the swelling of the limb has subsided, and the pain has been relieved.
Deinde itera ipsum ad stricturam subtilem, et emplastrum paruum: et non stringas ipsum constrictione tua prima, et subtilia cum eo, donec sanetur.	Then return to using a gentle bandage and a small plaster: and do not apply the first tight bandage or use gentle ones with it until he is healed.
Quod si uides, quod apostema, et rubedo, et dolor, et inflatio, et omnia accidentia iam remota sunt penitus, et indiges emplastro et strictura, tunc itera illud sicut fecisti in primis aequaliter.	If you see that the abscess, redness, pain, swelling, and all other symptoms have completely disappeared, and you need to apply a plaster and bandage, then proceed as you did initially, evenly.
Quod si non accidit membro aliquid ex eis quae diximus, tune non soluas ipsum, nisi post tres dies, aut quatuor, aut quinque, aut septem.	If nothing happens to the limb from what we have mentioned, then do not remove it [the bandage], unless after three days, or four, or five, or seven.
Et quando que dimittitur uiginti diebus totum illud, secundum quod apparet tibi ex solutione membri, sicut diximus, donec quando adhaeret fractura, et approximat coagulatio carnis super eam: adde etiam tunc in strictura plus quam strictura tua prima tota: et adde etiam in ingrossatione cibi infirmi, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius.	And when it is allowed to rest for twenty days, as you can tell from the removal of the bandage, as we said, until the bone adheres and the flesh coagulates over it: then add more binding than your first binding in total: and also increase the nourishment of the patient, according to what was mentioned before.
Si autem uides locum fracturae iam exiccari, et extenuari plus quam oportet: tunc scias, quod nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad ipsum.	If you see that the place of the fracture is already drying up and has become thinner than it should be: then you know that nourishment is prevented from reaching it.
Embroca ergo ipsum cum aqua tepida apud omnem uicem qua soluis ipsum, et sit illud in omnibus tribus diebus, et alleuia stricturam parumper.	Therefore, rinse it with warm water each time you wash it, and do this for all three days, and slightly loosen the bandage.
Per hanc ergo operationem currit ad membrum nutrimentum, et sanatur uelociter.	Through this operation, nourishment flows to the limb, and it heals quickly.
Illud autem quod faciunt stolidi restauratores ex fractura membri uice alia, quando non restauratur in primis, secundum quod oportet, et restauratur secundum tortuositatem, est error ex operatione eorum, et timor magnus: et si esset rectum, dixissent illud antiqui in libris suis, et operati fuissent cum eo.	What foolish healers do when they attempt to set a fractured limb incorrectly, failing to restore it properly as it should be done and instead setting it with a twist, is an error in their operation and causes great fear: and if this were the right way, the ancients would have written about it in their books and practiced it.
Et ego non uidi alicubi eorum uestigium in illo omnino, et rectius est, ut non fiat illud.	And I have not seen any trace of their method anywhere at all, and it is better that such a thing does not happen.
¶ De factura accidente in capite.	¶ On injuries to the head.
Caput III.	Chapter III.
Species fracturae sunt diuersae, et figurae eius multae: et caussae eius sunt distinctae.	The types of fractures are diverse, and their shapes are many: and the causes of them are distinct.
Nam ex fractura est quae fit a percussione cum ense: et percussio aufert os totum usquequo peruenit ad siphac, quod est sub osse, sicut facit axia in ligno: et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Axialis.	There is a fracture caused by a blow with a sword: and the impact removes the bone entirely to where it reaches the substance beneath the bone, just as an axe does in wood: and because of this, this type of fracture is called Axial.
Aut ensis incidit quiddam ossis, et incidit faciem eius, et non penetrat incisio usque ad ultimum eius: et nominatur haec species fracturae Kalaan, id est, Leuatio absolute.	Or the sword strikes some part of the bone and cuts its surface, but the cut does not penetrate to the very end of it: and this type of fracture is called Kalan, that is, Complete Contusion.
Et est uulnus duarum fracturarum, aut magnum, aut paruum.	And it is a wound of two fractures, either large or small.
Et ex fractura est, quae est contritio, aut attritio: et caussa eius est percussio cum lapide, aut casus super lapidem, aut eis similia.	And it is a fracture which is a breaking or wearing away: and its cause is a blow with a stone, or falling on a stone, or similar circumstances.
Et haec fractura est etiam aut penetrans, quae iam appropinquat panniculo, quod est sub osse: aut est in facie ossis: et est uulnus harum duarum fracturarum etiam aut paruum, aut magnum.	And this fracture is also either penetrating, which is now approaching the membrane beneath the bone, or it is on the surface of the bone: and the wound of these two fractures is also either small or large.
Et ex fractura est, quae est occulta in osse in subtilitate capilli: et est fissura parua, et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Capillaris.	And there is a fracture which is hidden within the bone with subtlety of a hair: and it is a small crack, and because of this it is named this type of fracture Capillaris.
Et ex eis est fractura, quae fit a casu, aut percussione lapidis, et eis similium, quae faciunt ingredi laminam ossis ad interiora, et fit loco concauitas: sicut accidit caldariis aeris, quando occurrit eis percussio, et ingreditur pars eorum ad interiora.	And among them is a fracture which occurs from a fall or blow by a stone, and similar incidents that cause a layer of bone to enter the interior, resulting in a concavity: just as it happens to those who work with metal vessels when they are struck, causing part of their body to be injured internally.
Et plurimum quidem fit illud in capitibus humidorum ossium, sicut sunt capita puerorum.	And this most often occurs in the heads of soft bones, such as the heads of children's bones.
Et fiunt omnibus istis speciebus fracturae satagiae separatae, et ego ueniam cum rememoratione illius totius in loco suo.	And these various types of fractures require separate treatments, and I will provide the remedy for each with its respective recall in its proper place.
Et cognoscimus omnes has species fracturae per detectionem super eam, et inquisitionem earum cum tentis, et ablationem carnium corruptarum, quae sunt super eas.	And we recognize all these types of fractures through examination on them, and investigation with probes, and removal of corrupted flesh that is above them.
Species uero Capillaris cognoscitur per hoc, quod detegitur super os, et abstergitur, et linitur super ipsum cum encaustro: fractura enim apparet nigra.	The Capillaris type of fracture is recognized by this method: it is uncovered on the bone, wiped clean, and then coated with encaustic wax; for the fracture appears black.
In curatione autem fracturae, considera in primis accidentia infirmi: tunc si uides ex accidentibus quod significet significatione manifesta super timorem, sicut uomitus cholerae, et extensio, et amissio intellectus, et abscisio uocis, et syncopis, et febris acuta, et egressus oculorum, et rubedo eorum, et similia eis ex accidentibus in pluribus dispositionibus, proculdubio non sanatur: et si uides accidentia non terrentia te, et speras salutem: tunc incipe curationem eius.	In treating a fracture, first consider the symptoms of the patient: then if you see from the symptoms that they indicate severe danger, such as vomiting like cholera, and stretching, and loss of consciousness, and cutting off speech, and syncope, and acute fever, and protrusion of the eyes, and redness of them, and similar things among the symptoms in many conditions, it is undoubtedly not healed: and if you see symptoms that do not terrify you, and hope for a cure: then begin the treatment of him.
Quod est, si uenit ad te uulneratus in primis cum uulneratur: et est illud in diebus hyemis, tunc oportet, ut studeas in ablatione ossis ante diem quartumdecimum secundum omnem dispositionem.	When someone comes to you wounded upon being injured, and this happens during the winter days, then it is necessary that you strive to remove the bone before the fourteenth day according to every condition.
Et si est in diebus aestatis, tunc oportet, ut properes remouere os ante diem septimum, antequam corrumpatur quod est sub osse ex panniculo, et accidant illa accidentia quae narrauimus.	And if it happens during the summer days, then you must hurry to remove the bone before the seventh day, before what is under the skin beneath the bone becomes corrupted, and those symptoms occur that we have mentioned.
Quod si fractura ossis iam peruenit ad panniculum tangentem cerebrum, et est cum minutiis, et attractione: tunc oportet, ut incidas partem comminutam, et attritam, secundum quod narro tibi.	If a fracture of the bone has reached the skin covering the brain, and it is accompanied by small pieces and adhesion: then you must cut away the broken and abraded parts as I describe to you.
Et est, ut radas caput uulnerati: et detege super os secundum quemcunque modum possibile est tibi: et secundum figuram uulneris, et quod leue est super infirmum.	And you should shave the head of the injured person: and expose the bone above it in whatever way is possible for you: and according to the shape of the wound, and what is light on the patient.
Quod si accidat tibi apud detectionem ossis fluxus sanguinis, aut apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet.	If during the exposure of the bone, there is a flow of blood or a hot abscess: then apply what is necessary to counter it.
Et est, ut impleas locum cum pannis infusis in uino, et oleo rosato: et facias quiescere uulnus, donec sedetur apostema, et sis securus a fluxu sanguinis.	And you should fill the wound with cloths soaked in wine and rose oil: and make the wound rest until the abscess subsides, and be secure from bleeding.
Deinde incipe in curatione ossis, et ablatione eius.	Then begin with the treatment of the bone, and its removal.
Et illud fit secundum unum duorum modorum.	And this is done according to one of two methods.
Modus quidem unus est, ut incidas os cum Incisorio strictae aciei: et haec est forma eius.	One method is to cut the bone with a sharp knife, and this is its form.
Dende administra Incisorium aliud post Incisorum latius eo parumper: et haec est forma eius.	Then apply another knife wider than the previous one after cutting: and this is its form.
Deinde administra etiam Incisorium aliud latius etiam quam secundum.	Then apply another knife even wider than the second one.
Et modus secundus est, ut sit apud te numerus Incisoriorum diuersorum: quorum quaedam sint latiora quibusdam, et quaedam eorum breuiora quibusdam: et sint in ultimo acuitatis extremitatum suarum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut fuled: et utere facilitate in percussione super Incisorium, ut non concutiat caput, et laedat ipsum.	And the second method is to have a number of different cutting instruments: some should be wider than others, and some shorter than others; they should be extremely sharp at their tips, and made of soft iron or steel; and use ease in striking above the knife so that it does not shake the head and injure it.
Si autem os est forte, durum: tunc oportet, ut perfores in circumitu eius, antequam tu administres Incisoria, cum Terebris quae nominantur Terebra non profundantia: et non nominantur ita, nisi quoniam ipsa non pertranseunt terminum ossis carnei ad illud, quod est post ipsum: propterea, quod Terebro est extremitas rotunda super illud, quod est sub capite eius acuto, similis margini, et circulus paruus prohibet submergi, et pertransire spissitudinem ossis.	If the bone is hard and strong, then it is necessary to drill around it before applying cutting instruments, using drills called non-penetrating trephines; they are not named thus unless they do not penetrate beyond the bony tissue to what lies behind it: because the tip of the trepan is round above what is under its sharp head, similar to an edge and a small circle prevents sinking and penetrating the density of the bone.
Et conuenit tibi, ut accipias ex istis Terebris numerum multum, quorum unumquodque conueniat quantitati spissitudinis ossis, donec praesens sit tibi omni craneo Terebrum: cuius extremitatis acutae quantitas in longitudine et breuitate sit, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis illius cranei.	And it is appropriate for you to take a variety of these trephines, each suitable to the density of the bone, until there is a trepan available for every part of the skull: the length and width of whose sharp tip should correspond to the density of that particular part of the skull.
Et haec est forma trium specierum Terebrorum, uel Trepanorum.	And this is the form of three types of borers, or trephines.
Qualitas autem perforandi in circumitu ossis fracti, est: ut ponas Terebrum super os, et reuoluas ipsum digitis tuis, donec scias, os iam penetratum esse.	The quality of piercing around the fractured bone is as follows: place the trepan on the bone and rotate it with your fingers until you know that the bone has been penetrated.
Deinde permuta Terebrum ad locum alium, et pone quod est inter omne foramen quantitatem grossitudinis radii, aut circiter illud.	Then move the trepan to another place and ensure that the distance between all the holes is the thickness of a finger, or thereabouts.
Deinde incide cum Incisoriis quod est inter omne foramen ex osse: et fac illud subtilius quam potes super illud ex fine leuitatis, sicut diximus, donec eradices os, aut manu tua, aut cum aliquo alio ex quibusdam instrumentis, quae parasti ad illud: sicut tenaliae, et forpices subtiles.	Then cut with the knives what is between each hole in the bone, and do it as finely as possible with a sharp edge, as we have said, until you remove the bone roots either by hand or with other instruments that you have prepared for this purpose, such as forceps and fine pincers.
Et oportet, ut caueas omni cautela, ne tangat Terebrum, aut Incisorium aliquid ex siphac.	And it is necessary to be extremely careful that the trepan or knife does not touch anything from the brain.
Cum ergo circumieris os perforando, et separatum fuerit a siphac, si fuerit continuum cum eo, et extraxeris ipsum, oportet ut radas, et aeques extremitatem eius quod remanet in osse cum instrumento alio simili Incisorio.	When you have thus perforated the bone and separated it from the brain, if it was connected to it, and you have removed it, you must then file and smooth the remaining edge with another instrument similar to a knife.
Verumtamen oportet, ut sit tenuis et subtilis magis aliis Incisoriis.	However, it is necessary for this instrument to be thinner and finer than other knives.
Quod si remanet aliquid ex ossibus paruis, et satagiae: tunc accipe ea cum facilitate, cum eo quod est apud te ex instrumentis.	If any small pieces of bone remain and need to be removed: then take them out easily with one of the instruments you have.
Deinde cura uulnus post illud cum liciniis, et unguentis quae diximus.	Then care for the wound afterwards with liniments and ointments as we have mentioned.
Et modus alius operationis est facilis, prorsus longinquus a timore: quem dixit Galenus, et laudauit ipsum laude magna: et iste est sermo eius.	And there is another method of operation that is easy and completely free from fear, which Galenus described and highly praised. This is his statement on it.
Necese est tibi in primis, ut incipias detegere partem ossis ex loco, in quo fractura est uehementior, et manifestior: donec quando detexeris illam partem, et posueris sub eo extremitatem huius Incisorii lenticularis, cuius haec est forma.	You must begin by uncovering the part of the bone in the place where the fracture is more severe and clearer. Once you have uncovered that part, place under it the tip of this lens-shaped incisor, which has this shape.
Et pars lenticularis, lenis non incidit aliquid: et pars acuta eius in duabus lateribus eius uadens in longitudinem, sicut uides: ut sit pars lenticularis innixa ad siphac, facie eius incidente acuta in osse.	And the lens-shaped part does not cut anything; and its sharp part running along both sides of it as you see: so that the lens-shaped part is attached to the saw, with its sharp edge facing into the bone.
Deinde percute super Incisorium a parte una cum malleo paruo, donec incidas totum os cum facilitate, sicut reuoluitur: et tu sis securus ex panniculo, quod non accidat in eo accidens, quod timeas prorsus.	Then strike above the Incisor with a small hammer from one side until you cut through all the bone easily, as it rotates: and be assured by the cloth that nothing will happen there that you fear completely. 
Et si medicans non esset stultior hominum, et magis ignarus eius, nec esset dormiens, tunc si remaneret aliquid annexum ossi ex panniculo in quibusdam locis, incideret ipsum ab eo cum extremitate incisorii lenticularis ipsius, et liberaret ipsum ab eo cum facilitate.	And if the physician were not more foolish than other men and less knowledgeable about it, nor were he sleeping, then if there remained any part attached to the bone from the fatty tissue in certain places, he would cut it away from it with the sharp edge of his knife, and free it from it with ease.
Liberatur enim ab eo sine nocumento, et absque timore.	He frees it from it without harm and without fear.
Et si fractura ossis non penetret usque ad panniculum, et illud quod abscinditur ab osse est facies eius, et remanent in ipso asperitas et satagiae subtiles: tunc oportet, ut radas illam asperitatem, et eradices illas satagias cum rasoriis subtilibus ex quibus praeparasti numerum diuersarum quantitatum, ut sit tibi possibile administrare ex eis in omni loco conuenientiora eorum, et rectiora ipsorum, secundum illud ad quod perducit te operatio, et ipsum os fractum, et figura eius.	And if the fracture of the bone does not penetrate to the fatty tissue, and what is severed from the bone is its surface, and there remain in it fine roughnesses and protrusions: then you must scrape that roughness, and remove those protrusions with finely prepared razors of various sizes, so that you can apply appropriately sized and straightened pieces according to what guides you in your operation, to the fractured bone, and to its shape.
Et oportet, ut administres in rasione tua, qua in primis radis os, latius illorum rasoriorum.	And you must apply with your reason, first scraping the bone more broadly with those razors.
Deinde utere post ipsum subtiliore eo.	Then use a finer one afterwards.
Et non cesses facere illud secundum continuitatem, donec peruenias ad administrandum tenuius, et subtilius eorum omnium.	And do not stop doing this continuously until you reach the point of applying the finest and most subtle of them all.
In unaquaque autem fissurarum reliquarum paruarum capillarium, et fractura subtili, oportet ut administres curam, secundum illud quod perducit ad rectificationem eius.	In each of the remaining small hairline cracks and in a subtle fracture, you must apply care according to what leads to its correction.
Et est res quae non occultatur super omnem, cui in hac arte est quodlibet studium, et stetit super illud quod scripsimus, et ostendimus in fracturis magnis.	And this is a matter that is not hidden from anyone who has any interest in this art, and it stands out among what we have written and shown regarding major fractures.
Si autem panniculus detectus retinetur, quando tu eradicas os: tunc oportet, ut accipias pannum lini, secundum quantitatem uulneris, et submerge ipsum in oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super orificium uulneris.	But if the fatty tissue is exposed and retained when you are removing the bone: then you must take a piece of linen according to the size of the wound, dip it in rose oil, and place it over the opening of the wound.
Deinde accipe pannum alium duplicatum, aut triplicatum, et submerge ipsum in uino et oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super pannum primum: et fac illud quam facilius potes super illud, ut non grauetur siphac.	Then take another doubled or tripled cloth and immerse it in wine and rose oil, and place it over the first cloth: and do this as easily as possible so that it does not become too heavy to manage.
Deinde administra supra ipsum ligamentum latum: et non stringas ipsum, nisi per quantitatem quae teneat uulnus tantum: et dimitte ipsum cum hac cura die uno, aut diebus duobus, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido.	Then apply a broad bandage over it: and do not bind it tightly except to the extent that it holds the wound only: and leave it with this care for one day or two days until you are secure from a hot abscess.
Deinde solue ipsum, et administra post illud medicinas cum quibus est superflua siccitas: sicut radices lilii, et farina herbi, et puluis thuris, et aristolochia, et similia eis: et est, ut facias ex istis medicinis puluerem, qui puluerizetur super uulnus sicut sunt siccae.	Then remove it, and apply after this medicines that are used for excessive dryness: such as roots of lilies, flour of the plant, and powder of frankincense, and aristolochia, and similar to these: and make a powder from these medicines, which should be dusted over the wound as needed for dryness.
Et uniuersaliter administra in illo omnem medicinam de proprietate cuius est ut abstergat, et non mordicet.	And generally apply to it any medicine that has the property of cleaning without irritating.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, ut uulnus in curatione tua sit limpidum: neque sit in ea sordes unguenti, neque sordicies.	And be cautious according to your ability, so that the wound in your care is clear: neither should there be dirt from ointment nor impurities.
Neque dimittas uirus aggregari in eo omnino: quoniam quando uirus aggregatur super panniculum cerebri, corrumpit eum, et putrefacit ipsum, et accidit super infirmum post illud malicia magna: et iam accidit in siphac capitis, cum mundificatur ab eo os, praecipue quando negligitur cura eius, nigredo in superficie eius.	And do not allow any pus to accumulate in it at all: for when pus accumulates on the membrane of the brain, it corrupts and putrefies it, and afterwards causes great harm to the patient: and it often leads to siphac of the head, when the wound heals from it, especially when its care is neglected, blackness appears on its surface.
Considera ergo tunc, si accidunt infirmo accidentia quae diximus, scias, quia est pernitiosum proculdubio.	Therefore, if the patient experiences any of the symptoms we have mentioned, you should know that it is certainly dangerous.
Et si nigredo non accidit, nisi a medicina quae ponitur super ipsum, et est in uirtute illius medicinae, ut faciat illam nigredinem: tunc oportet, ut accipias ex melle partem unam, ex oleo rosato partes tres, et linias cum eis pannum.	And if blackness does not occur except from the medicine that is applied to it, and this medicine has the property of causing that blackness: then you should take one part honey, three parts rose oil, and use these to moisten a cloth.
Deinde pone ipsum super siphac: postea cura ipsum cum speciebus curationis quae conueniunt, donec sanetur.	Then place it on a pillow; afterwards care for it with remedies that are appropriate until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione Nasi quando frangitur.	Concerning the restoration of the nose when it is broken.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV.
Scias, quod non franguntur ex Naso nisi duae partes eius superiores simul, aut una earum: propterea, quod ipse sunt duo ossa: quoniam inferius eius est cartilaginosum, non frangitur, et non accidit ei nisi attritio, et tortuositas, et simitas.	Know that the nose is not broken except in its two upper parts simultaneously or one of them, because they are the two bones; since the lower part of it is cartilage, it does not break but only suffers wear, and distortion, and deformation.
Si frangitur una duarum partium eius, tunc oportet, ut intromittas digitum paruum in foramen Nasi, et aeques illam fracturam digito tuo indice, et pollice deforis, donec redeat Nasus super figuram suam naturalem: et fiat illud arte, cum facilitate.	If one of the two parts is broken, then you must insert your small finger into the nostril and adjust the fracture with your index finger and thumb from outside until the nose returns to its natural shape. This should be done skillfully and easily.
Et caue, ne accidat per operationem tuam illam super infirmum dolor.	And be careful that your treatment does not cause pain to the patient.
Quod si fractura est in superiore parte Nasi, et non perueniat ad illam digitus: tunc oportet, ut aequetur extremitate radii, in quo sit grossitudo parua.	If the fracture is in the upper part of the nose and your finger cannot reach it, then you must adjust it with the edge of a rod that has a small thickness.
Si uero fractura est in duabus partibus, tunc fac simile illius: et propera cum restauratione eius in die primo fracturae, si est possibile.	If the fracture is in both parts, then proceed similarly: and hurry with its restoration on the first day of the fracture, if it is possible.
Et si non, tunc post diem septimum, aut decimum apud quietem apostematis calidi.	And if not, then after the seventh or tenth day when the inflammation has subsided.
Deinde intromitte in extremitate Nasi licinium ex panno lini, si fractura est in parte una: aut intromite duo licinia si fractura est in duabus partibus: et sit in licinio grossitudo tantae quantitatis, quae impleat foramen Nasi.	Then insert into the nostril a wick made of linen cloth if the fracture is in one part; or insert two wicks if the fracture is in both parts: and let the thickness of the wick be such that it fills the nostril.
Et dixerunt quidam antiquorum restauratorum, ut infundantur licinia in butyro, et permutentur omni die.	And certain of the ancient restorers said that they should be infused into licorice dissolved in butter, and should be changed every day.
Illud uero non uidetur mihi, imo oportet, ut infundatur licinium in albugine oui, confecto cum puluere molendini.	But that does not seem right to me; rather, it must be infused with licorice in egg white, prepared with flour powder.
Deinde dimitte licinium, donec firmetur os, et induretur cartilago.	Then let the licorice be removed until the bone hardens and the cartilage becomes firm.
Et quandoque intromittitur in Nasum loco licinii penna anseris, postquam inuoluitur super ipsam pannus lenis: et fit, quod ipsa tenet fracturam Nasi uehementius, et ut non prohibeatur infirmus ab inspiratione.	And sometimes a goose feather is inserted into the nose instead of licorice, after it is wrapped in soft cloth; and this holds the fracture of the nose more firmly and allows the patient to breathe without obstruction.
Et non est haec res necessaria.	And this is not necessary.
Si uis, fac illud: et si uis, fac licinia.	If you wish, do it; and if you wish, use the licorice.
Quod si accidat Naso iterum dum operaris apostema calidum, emplastra nasum cum caeroto, aut cum coto infuso in oleo rosato, aut modico ex dyaquilon.	If it happens that the nose again becomes infected with a hot abscess while you are treating it, apply plasters to the nose made with pitch, or with cotoneaster infused in rose oil, or a little dragon's blood.
Si autem non accidit apostema calidum, tunc oportet, ut emplastres ipsum cum farina sisami, et puluere thuris confecti cum albugine oui.	But if it does not become a hot abscess, then plasters should be applied to it made with sesame flour and thuja powder prepared with egg white.
Deinde pone super ipsum stuppam lenem, et non liges Nasum cum aliquo omnino.	Then place a soft linen bandage over it, and do not bind the nose with anything at all.
Si uero franguntur ossa Nasi fractura parua, aut comminuuntur, tunc oportet, ut scindas super ea, et extrahas ipsa cum instrumentis quae conueniunt eis.	But if the bones of the nose are fractured slightly or crushed, then it is necessary to cut them open and extract them with instruments that are suitable for them.
Deinde sue scissuram, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat, et consolidat ex emplastris conuenientibus ad illud, uel unguentis.	Then close the wound, and treat it with something that promotes flesh growth and consolidation using appropriate plasters or ointments.
Quod si accidat inter Nasum uulnus, tunc oportet, ut cures ipsum cum liciniis: et administres cannulam de plumbo, donec sanetur.	If it happens that a wound occurs to the nose, then you must treat it with bandages: and administer a tube of lead until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Mandibulae inferioris, quando disrumpitur.	Regarding the restoration of the lower jaw when it is fractured.
Caput V.	Chapter 5.
Quando disrumpitur Mandibula inferior, et fractura eius non est cum uulnere: conspice tunc si est fractura eius deforis tantum, et non frangitur in duo, et curuatur ad interiora: tunc cognitio eius est facilis.	When the lower jaw is fractured, and the fracture is not accompanied by a wound: observe then if the fracture is only on the outer side, and it does not break into two pieces, and curves inward: then diagnosing it is easy.
Oportet ergo, si est fractura eius in parte dextra, ut intromittas digitum indicem sinistrae in os infirmi: similiter si fractura est in mandibula sinistra, tunc intromitte indicem manus dextrae: et impelle cum eo gibbositatem fracturae deintus cum facilitate ad exteriora cum manu tua altera ab interiori parte ossis decenter, et cum eo aequa ipsam.	Therefore, if the fracture is on the right side, insert your index finger of the left hand into the mouth of the patient: similarly, if the fracture is on the left jaw, then insert your index finger of the right hand: and push with it the bump of the fracture from the inside to the outside easily with your other hand from the inner part of the bone appropriately, and even it out with it.
Quod si fractura mandibulae iam separata est in duo, tunc oportet, ut administres extersionem a duabus partibus, secundum rectitudinem: donec possibilis sit aequatio eius.	If the fracture of the jaw has already separated into two parts, then you must administer an extension from both sides, according to straightness: until it is possible to even it out.
Si autem iam accidit in dentibus commotio, aut disruptio: tunc stringe illos de quibus speras quod remaneant cum filo auri, aut argenti, aut seta.	If, however, a movement or disruption has already occurred in the teeth: then bind those that you hope will remain with gold thread, silver thread, or silk.
Deinde pone super mandibulam fractam caerotum.	Then place beeswax over the fractured jaw.
Deinde pone super ipsum pannum duplicatum, et pone super pannum astellam magnam decenter factam: aut frustum cutis soleae aequale, in longitudinem mandibulae.	Then place a doubled cloth over it, and put a large bandage properly made on top of the cloth: or a piece of leather sole equal in length to the jaw.
Deinde liga ipsum desuper, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ligatura eius, et conuenit ipsius applicatio, donec non destruitur: et praecipe infirmo, uti tranquillitate et quiete: et pone cibum eius sorbitiones lenes.	Then bind it from above as the binding is prepared for you, and apply it until it is not destroyed: and instruct the patient to be tranquil and at rest: and give the patient soft absorbent foods.
Si autem estimas, quod iam alteratur aliquid figurae aliquo modorum: tunc propera, et solue ipsum in die tertio.	If you think that something has already changed in its shape in some way, then hurry and dissolve it on the third day.
Deinde rectifica quod alteratum est ex eo, et emplastra ipsum ex puluere molendini, cum albugine oui, aut cum farina sisami, postquam tu abstuleris caerotum: et pone super emplastrum lanam lenem.	Then correct what has been altered from it, and apply a poultice made of ground flour, with egg white, or with sesame flour, after you have removed the dressings: and place soft wool over the poultace.
Dum ergo permanet annexum illud emplastrum super ipsum, et non alteratur ossis dispositio, dimitte ipsum, ne soluas, donec sanetur: aut stringe fracturam.	While the poultice remains attached to it and the bone's position does not change, leave it as is, do not dissolve it until it heals: or compress the fracture.
Multotiens enim stringitur haec fractura in tribus septimanis.	This fracture is often compressed for three weeks.
Quod si interim accidat apostema calidum, tunc administra illud quod diximus multotiens in sedatione eius, donec remoueatur illud apostema.	If during this time a hot abscess occurs, then administer what we have mentioned multiple times for its reduction, until the abscess is removed.
Et si fractura est cum uulnere, considera.	And if there is a fracture with a wound, consider it carefully.
Namsi iam separatur ex osse frustum, aut a satagie: tunc subtilia te in hoc, ut auferas illa frusta satagiae cum eo quod conuenit tibi in ablatione eorum ex instrumentis.	If a piece has separated from the bone or from the surrounding tissue, then carefully remove those pieces of tissue along with what is necessary for their removal using instruments.
Si uero orificium uulneris est strictum, tunc amplifica ipsum cum phlebotomo secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	If the opening of the wound is narrow, then enlarge it with a scalpel according to the extent of what is necessary.
Deinde quando abstuleris illa satagie, et non remanserit ex eis aliquid, sue tunc orificium uulneris, si est amplum: et si non, pone super ipsum ex emplastris quae conueniunt ad illud, et incarnant illud, donec sanetur.	Then when you have removed that tissue and nothing of it remains, or if the opening of the wound is large: and if not, apply poultices suitable for it that promote healing, until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Furculae, quando frangitur.	Regarding the restoration of the Clavicle, when it is fractured.
Caput VI.	Chapter VI.
Plurimum quidem frangitur Furcula ab anteriore parte ex parte humeri, et fractura eius fit secundum unum trium modorum.	The furca (shoulder blade) is often fractured from its anterior part towards the shoulder, and this fracture occurs in one of three ways.
Aut enim frangitur et separatur in duo, praeter quod accidant in ea satagiae: et est facilius ad restaurationem eius.	Or it is broken and separated into two parts, and there may be some effort or struggle associated with this; however, it is easier to restore.
Aut ita, quod accidunt in osse satagiae: et est difficilius ad restaurationem.	Or it happens that there are efforts or struggles within the bone itself: and this is more difficult to restore.
Aut ita, quod est fractura cum uulnere.	Or it is a fracture with a wound.
Et operatio in ea quando fractura est absque uulnere, est, ut facias praesentes esse duos ministros, ut teneat unus eorum adiutorium quod sequitur Furculam fractam, et alter extendat collum uersus partem.	And when the fracture is without a wound, the procedure is to have two assistants present: one to hold the uninjured arm that follows the fractured furca, and the other to extend the neck towards the affected side.
Deinde aequa fracturam digitis tuis, donec fiat forma eius, secundum quod oportet: et non sit in ea eminentia, neque concauitas.	Then use your fingers to even out the fracture until its form is as it should be: there should be no protrusions or凹陷。为了保持翻译的流畅性和一致性，更好的译文是：
Quod si indiges extensione plus, tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico infirmi spheram ex panno, aut lana: et sit magnitudo eius secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae: et extende, et eleua Furculam, et coarta spheram manu tua, donec aeques fracturam, secundum quod oportet.	If you need more extension, then you must place under the anvil of the patient a sphere made of cloth or wool: and let its size be according to your need: and extend, and raise the lever, and compress the sphere with your hand until it evens out the fracture as is necessary.
Quod si non potes trahere extremitatem Furculae ad exteriora: propterea, quia peruenit ad profundum: tunc oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et ponas sub humero eius puluinar medium in magnitudine, et premat minister humerum eius ad inferiora, donec eleuetur os Furculae quod est in profundo ad sursum: atque tunc rectifica fracturam, et aequa eam digitis tuis.	If you are unable to pull the end of the lever to the exterior because it has reached the depth: then the patient must be laid back on his neck: and place under his shoulder a medium-sized cushion, and have an assistant press down on his shoulder until the part of the lever that is in the depth is raised upward: and then correct the fracture and make it even with your fingers.
Si autem sentis sathaiatum ex Furcula, et mouetur: tunc oportet, ut findas super illud, et extrahas ipsum alsathaiatum cum facilitate.	If you feel that there is a splinter from the lever and it moves: then you must cut above it, and extract the splinter with ease.
Si autem est retentum in osse, tunc ingenia in incisione eius cum uno Incisoriorum quae praeparasti ad illud, postquam tu posueris sub Furcula instrumentum quod seruat sifach: et est instrumentum ex ligno, aut ex ferro.	If it is retained in the bone, then use your skill in cutting it with one of the cutters you have prepared for this purpose, after placing under the lever an instrument that prevents slipping: and this instrument is made of wood or iron.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Assimilatur cochleari cui non est concauitas.	It resembles a spoon that does not have a concavity.
Et sit latitudo eius secundum illud quo indiges eo ex magnitudine ossis, et paruitate eius.	And let its width be according to what you need in relation to the size and shape of the bone.
Longitudo uero eius etiam secundum quod possibile est tibi ad operationem.	And its length should also be as much as possible for you according to the operation.
Et habeat duas extremitates, sicut uides: et extremitas una sit ampla, et altera stricta.	And it should have two ends, as you can see: one end wide, and the other narrow.
Si autem disruptio uulneris quod scidisti quando extraxisti sathaiatum ossis, est ampla, et securaris ab apostemate calido: tunc aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura.	If the tearing of the wound you cut when you extracted the splintered bone is wide, and you are treating an abscess with a warm application: then bring together the two lips of the wound with stitches.
Et si disruptio est parua, aut times apostema calidum: tunc imple uulnus cum pannis, et puluillis secundum quantitatem scissurae uulneris.	And if the tearing is small, or you fear a warm abscess: then fill the wound with cloths and poultices according to the size of the wound's tear.
Quod si accidat apostema calidum, tunc infunde pannum in oleo rosato, et aceto, et uino, et pone super ipsum.	If a warm abscess should occur, then soak a cloth in rose oil, vinegar, and wine, and place it upon the wound.
Strictura uero ossis quando est absque uulnere, et absque sectione, est, ut ponas super os emplastrum factum ex farina molendini cum albugine oui.	However, when the constriction of a bone occurs without a wound and without a fracture, you should apply a plaster made from flour from the mill mixed with egg white.
Et pone stuppam lenem super ipsum.	And place a soft bandage on it.
Deinde pone spheram sub titillico eius, si indiges illa.	Then place a sphere under its armpit, if you need to do so.
Deinde accipe himematem, id est, rotam quam tenent Saraceni, quae sit longa ualde: et sit latitudo eius palmi unius, aut circiter illud.	Then take a himematem, that is, a roll which the Saracens hold, which should be very long: and its width should be one palm, or about that.
Deinde pone puluillum duplicatum super stuppam et emplastrum.	Then place a double poultice on the bandage and plaster.
Deinde accipe astellam ex tabula subtili, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, et in longitudine similiter.	Then take a thin stick from a slender board, whose width is three fingers, and its length should be similar.
Deinde inuolue eam in panno.	Then wrap it in cloth.
Deinde inuolue pannum illum cum astella in loco alhimemati qui cadit super fracturam et locum.	Then wrap the cloth with the stick in the place where the himematem falls over the fracture and the area around it.
Deinde pone alhimemati super fracturam sicut reuoluiur, et inuolue eam super collum eius, et sub titillico eius sano, et sub titillico eius infirmo: et reduc eam super omnem partem, et quomodo uides quod strictura tenet fracturam strictura decenti: et est illud, quod non occultatur super te, et totum, ut non remoueatur astella desuper os fractum.	Then place the himematem over the fracture as it wraps, and wrap it around the neck, under the healthy armpit, and under the injured armpit: and bring it back over every part, and make sure that the constriction holds the fracture properly: and this is not hidden from you, and all of it so that the stick does not come off above the broken bone.
Et propter hoc oportet, ut aspicias infirmum in omni die.	And for this reason it is necessary that you look at the sick person every day.
Quotiens ergo mollificatur ligamentum, et uides astellam iam remoueri: tunc rectifica illud, et stringe ligamentum.	Therefore, whenever the ligature is softened and you see that the arrow is already removed: then straighten it, and tighten the ligature.
Deinde pone somnum infirmi super dorsum eius, et pone sub titillico eius apud somnum eius puluinar paruum in nocte, ut cum eo eleuetur adiutorium eius a latere ipsius.	Then place the pillow of the patient's head on his back, and place a small cushion near his pillow at night, so that when he is raised help comes from his side.
Eleuatur ergo fractura furculae per eleuationem humeri.	Therefore, the fracture of the collarbone should be elevated by raising the shoulder.
Aut liga brachium eius ad collum ipsius: et non soluas ligamentum, si non accidat in loco accidens ex pruritu, aut ab apostemate, usque ad duodecim dies.	Or bind his arm to his neck: and do not remove the ligature unless an incident occurs due to itching or from an abscess, until twelve days have passed.
Deinde renoua emplastrum, si uideris faciem eius ad illud.	Then renew the plaster if you see that his condition requires it.
Et adde in strictura, et dimitte ipsum, donec restauretur et coaguletur.	And add to the binding, and leave it as is until it restores and heals.
Et fractura quidem furculae stringitur et confortatur secundum plurimum in uigintiocto diebus: et quandoque fit in quibusdam hominibus in minore illo.	And a fracture of the collarbone is tightly bound and strengthens mostly within twenty-eight days: and sometimes it happens in some people in less than that.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spatulae.	Concerning the restoration of a spoon-shaped fracture.
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.
Raro frangitur Spatula, et in loco lato eius: et non franguntur ex ea nisi margines eius.	The spoon-shaped bone is rarely fractured, and when it occurs, it affects its broad part: and fractures do not occur in it except at its edges.
Quando ergo frangitur ex eo locus, et frangitur in medio eius, et non cognoscitur illud nisi per tactum: tunc secundum quod est figura fracturae conare praeparationem eius.	When it is fractured from that part and breaks in the middle, and this cannot be known except by touch: then according to the shape of the fracture, attempt its preparation.
Et reduc eam super figuram naturalem omni modo ingenii, quod est tibi possibile.	And restore it to its natural shape in every way that is possible for you.
Deinde pone super locum puluerem molendini cum albugine oui, et stuppam lenem, et pone desuper puluillum ex panno duplato.	Then place powdered meal with egg white on the site, and a soft cloth, and put a powder above from doubled fabric.
Deinde pone super ipsum astellam latam ex tabula subtili secundum quantitatem Spatulae totius, aut ampliorem ea parum.	Then place a broad strip of thin wood on it according to the length of the entire spatula, or slightly larger than that.
Si uero sub astella est concauitas in aliquo locorum Spatulae, tunc aequa illam concauitatem cum stuppa leni, donec descendat astella secundum aequalitatem.	But if there is a concavity under the strip of wood at any part of the spatula, then even out that concavity with soft lint until the strip of wood descends evenly.
Deinde ftringe desuper cum alhimemati longa, constrictione decenti, et firmitudine astellae, donec non remoueatur a loco suo.	Then bind it above with linen strips, in a proper constriction and with the firmness of the strip of wood, until it does not move from its place.
Et considera ligamentum in omni die.	And examine the bandage every day.
Quotienscunque ergo mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum, et aequa astellam si remoueatur a loco suo: et iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	Whenever the bandage becomes loose, tighten it, and even out the strip if it has moved from its place: and let the patient lie on their healthy side.
Et Spatula quidem restauratur in uiginti diebus, aut in uigintiquinque diebus.	And the spatula is restored in twenty days, or in twenty-five days.
Quando ergo completur iste numerus, tunc solue ligamentum: et tu sis in securitate.	When this number is complete, then remove the bandage: and you may be at ease.
Nam ipsa est ex ossibus quorum communitio non timetur, neque eorum solutio.	For these bones do not fear the union of their connection nor the separation of them.
Si autem procedat ex osse frustum, et pungit sub cute: tune scinde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum.	If a piece of bone protrudes and irritates the skin, then cut above it, and remove it.
Et fac quod diximus in fractura furculae ex sedatione apostematis calidi, si accidat ex eo aliquid.	And do as we said for the treatment of a broken collarbone to reduce an abscess with heat, if anything like that should occur.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Pectoris.	Of the restoration of a fracture of the Chest.
Caput VIII.	Chapter VIII.
Pectus quandoque frangitur in medio sui, et raro accidit illud.	The chest is sometimes fractured in the middle, and this rarely happens.
Extremitates eius quidem plurimum franguntur, et comminuuntur ex accidentibus eius.	The extremities of it are fractured and crushed more frequently due to accidents.
Quando frangitur eius medium, quod declinat ad inferiora, et accidit ei dolor uehemens, et difficultas in anhelitu, et tussis: et fortasse euomit sanguinem, et declaratur concauitas in osse fracto, et non occultatur sensui, Restauratio eius est, ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et pone inter Spatulas eius puluinar.	When its middle is fractured, causing it to incline downward, there is severe pain and difficulty in breathing, as well as coughing: and perhaps he vomits blood, and a concavity becomes apparent in the broken bone, which is not hidden from perception. Its restoration is such that the patient should be laid supine on his back: and place a cushion between the splints.
Deinde preme humeros eius, et aggrega costas a duabus partibus uel lateribus cum manibus: et subtiliare in aequatione eius, secundum omnem modum quo possibile est illud et conuenit, donec redeat figura ossis, secundum quod oportet.	Then press his shoulders, and bring together the ribs from both sides with your hands: and adjust it evenly, in every way that is possible and suitable, until the shape of the bone returns as it should.
Deinde pone super ipsum emplastrum et stuppam, et pone desuper astellam ex tabula subtili ex salice, aut chalingi, et ex eis similibus in leuitate, postquam tu inuoluis eam in panno.	Then place a plaster and linen bandage over it, and put a light board from willow or calamus, or similar lightweight materials, on top after wrapping it in cloth.
Deinde subtiliare in ligando eam super os fractum, ut non remoueatur: et uade cum ligatura secundum rotunditatem ad dorsum aliquotiens, et stringe ipsum strictura decenti.	Then carefully wrap it over the broken bone so that it does not move: and proceed with the bandaging around the body several times, and secure it tightly as needed.
Deinde considera ligaturam in omni hora, et quotienscumque mollificatur, stringe eam: et si necessitas eius prouocat ad solutionem eius apud pruritum, uel corrosionem quae accidit in loco, aut dolorem, aut apostema: tunc propera, et solue eam, et eradica emplastrum, et rectifica quod accidit cum modo curationis eius.	Then examine the bandaging at every hour, and whenever it becomes loose, tighten it: and if his condition requires that it be removed due to itching, or corrosion that occurs in the area, or pain, or abscess: then hurry and remove it, and clean off the plaster, and treat what has occurred according to the method of his care.
Deinde reduc emplastrum, si uides ad illud faciem: et annecte ei stricturam, donec sanetur.	Then apply a poultice if you see that it is necessary for the face: and attach a bandage to it tightly until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Costarum, quando franguntur.	On the restoration of broken ribs.
Caput IX.	Chapter IX.
Scias, quod Costarum fractura non accidit, nisi in locis grossis quae sequuntur dorsum, et ex extremitatibus earum ab anteriori parte.	Know that the fracture of ribs does not occur except in thick parts which follow the back, and from their extremities towards the front part.
Et non accidit eis attritio, nisi propterea, quia sunt cartilaginosae.	And wear and tear does not occur to them except because they are cartilaginous.
Et cognitio ipsius non occultatur sensui apud inquisitionem cum digitis.	And the knowledge of it is not hidden from the sense during examination with fingers.
Et restauratio eius fit ita, ut aeques fracturam cum digitis secundum modum possibilem, donec aequetur figura, secundum quod oportet.	And the restoration of it is such that you should equalize the fracture with your fingers according to the possible manner, until the figure is even as required.
Deinde emplastra, et stringe os fractum cum astella, si indiget illo.	Then apply plasters and bind the fractured bone with a splint if it requires one.
Et si fractura Costarum est decliuis ad interiora: tunc accidit infirmo dolor uehemens, et punctura, sicut punctura illa quae accidit illi qui habet pleuresim: propterea, quod os pungit uelamen, et etiam ei accidit difficultas anhelitus, et tussis, et uomitus sanguinis multi: et haec est difficilis curationis.	And if the fracture of the ribs is displaced towards the interior: then it causes the patient severe pain and piercing sensation, like that which occurs to one who has pleurisy: because the bone pierces the membrane, and also it causes difficulty in breathing, coughing, and vomiting of much blood: and this is difficult to cure.
Et iam ingeniati sunt antiqui in ea cum ingeniis multis: et ex eis sunt qui dicunt, ut ponas cibos infirmi qui generent inflammationem et uentositatem, ut inflammetur uenter, et extendatur, et impellatur fractura ad exteriora.	And the ancients have devised many devices for this: and among them are those who say that you should give the patient foods that generate inflammation and gas, so that the belly becomes inflamed, expands, and pushes the fracture outward.
Nos uero abhorremus, ut non fiat caussa uelox ad faciendum apostema calidum, si non accidit.	We, however, avoid it so that it does not become a cause for quickly forming a hot abscess, if one has not already occurred.
Si autem iam accidit, tunc addit in eo.	If it has already happened, then he adds to it.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum: ponatur super locum uentosa, deinde sugatur cum fortitudine, et est similius ratiocinationi.	And some of them said: Place the suction cup over the area, then pull it with strength, and it is similar to reasoning.
Verumtamen timetur, quod attrahat uentosa superfluitates ad locum, propter dispositionem debilitatis.	However, it is feared that the suction cups will draw excesses to the area due to the disposition of weakness.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum: oportet ut cooperiatur locus cum lana quae iam submersa est in oleo calido: et ponantur puluilli inter Costas, donec impleatur: ut sit ligatura aequalis quando inuoluis eam secundum rotunditatem.	And some of them said: The area must be covered with wool that has already been submerged in hot oil: and place poultices between the ribs until it is full: so that there is an equal binding when you wrap it according to its roundness.
Deinde curetur infirmus curatione pleuresis ex cibo et medicina.	Then the patient should be treated for pleurisy with food and medicine.
Quod si coartat infirmum res uehemens, quam non tolerat, et os pungit uelamen punctura laedente, et timemus super infirmum: tunc oportet, ut scindamus super locum, et detegamus a Costa fracta.	If the patient is constricted by something violent that they cannot tolerate, and the covering pierces the skin with painful punctures, and we fear for the patient: then it is necessary to cut open the area and expose the fractured rib.
Deinde ponamus super ea instrumentum quod conseruat sifac, cuius rememoratio praecessit: et incidamus os cum facilitate, et incidamus ipsum.	Then place the instrument that preserves the skin, which was mentioned earlier: and cut the covering with ease, and do it carefully.
Deinde aggregemus duo labia uulneris, si est magnum cum sutura: et curemus ipsum cum emplastris, donec sanetur.	Then bring together the two edges of the wound if it is large with stitches: and treat it with plasters until it heals.
Quod si accidat interim apostema calidum, tunc propera, et infunde puluillos in oleo rosato, et pone super locum: et curetur infirmus cum eo quod conuenit apostemati.	If an inflamed abscess occurs meanwhile, then hurry and infuse poultices in rose oil, and place them on the area: and treat the patient with what is appropriate for the abscess.
Interim etiam resupinetur super latus super quod dormit, donec sanetur.	In the meantime, let them lie on their side on which they sleep, until they heal.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spondilium dorsi et colli.	Of the restoration of a fracture of the vertebrae of the back and neck.
Caput X.	Chapter 10.
Ossibus quidem colli quandoque aduenit fractura, et raro accidit eis attritio: et similiter Spondilibus dorsi etiam.	Fractures can occur in the neck vertebrae at times, and wear is rarely observed in them; similarly, this is also the case for the vertebrae of the back.
Cum ergo accidit illud alicui, et uis scire, an sanetur, an non sanetur: tunc confidera.	When such an injury occurs to someone and you wish to know whether it can be healed or not, then proceed with caution.
Nam si uides manus eius iam mollificatas, et stupefactas, et mortuas: et non potest mouere eas, neque extendere eas, neque constringere eas: et quando constringis eas cum digitis tuis, et pungis eas cum acu, non sentit illud, et non sentit in eis dolorem: tunc scias, quia non sanatur, et in pluribus dispositionibus est mortale.	For if you see that his hands have already become soft, numb, and lifeless: and he cannot move them, nor stretch them out, nor clench them: and when you press them with your fingers or prick them with a needle, he does not feel it, and does not feel pain in them: then you will know that it is not healable, and in many cases it is fatal.
Quod si mouet eas, et sentit in eis constrictionem cum digitis et puncturam: tunc scias, quia nucha ossis salua est, et quod infirmus sanabitur cum curatione.	But if he can move them and feel the pressure from your fingers and the pricks: then you will know that the vertebrae are safe, and that the patient will be healed with treatment.
Quod si eueniat Spondilibus dorsi simile illius, et uis scire, an sanetur etiam, an non: tunc considera ad pedes eius: tunc si uides quod mollificati sunt, et accidit in eis illud quod accidit in manibus: deinde quando iacet super dorsum suum, egreditur uentositas et egestio absque uoluntate: et quando resupinatur super uentrem suum, egreditur egestio sine uoluntate: et quando resupinatur super dorsum suum, et uult mingere, et non potest: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If a similar condition affects the vertebrae of the back and you wish to know whether it can be healed or not: then consider his feet. If you see that they have become soft and the same thing happens to them as happened to the hands: and when he lies on his back, flatulence and evacuation occur without volition: and when he lies face down, evacuation occurs without volition: and when he lies on his back again and wishes to urinate but cannot: then you will know that it is fatal.
Non ergo labores in curatione eius.	Do not therefore labor in treating him.
Si uero non accidit ei aliquid ex illo, res est leuior.	If nothing happens to him because of that, the matter is lighter.
Et curatio eius quod accidit ex illo est, ut coneris sedationem apostematis calidi: ita, ut ponas super Spondilem attritam oleum rosatum solum: aut cum uitellis oui assati.	And the treatment for what happens because of that is to try to reduce the abscess with warm applications; thus, place on the swollen area rubbed rose oil alone or with eggs of roasted chicken.
Pone super ipsam illud aliquotiens in die, donec quando sedatur apostema calidum: tum pone super locum unum ex emplastris confortantibus, exiccantibus, et stringe super ipsum cum ligamento: et praecipe infirmo, ut utatur quiete et tranquillitate.	Place that on it several times a day until the warm abscess is reduced; then apply one of the firming, drying plasters to the area and bind it with a bandage; and instruct the patient to use rest and tranquility.
Nec dormiat super partem cum qua inuenit dolorem, donec sanetur.	And let him not sleep on the side where he feels pain until it is healed.
Quod si accidit apud attritionem ossis sathaiatum, aut aliquid quod iam separatum fit ex eo: tunc oportet, ut seces super cutem, et auferas illud.
